"[215-archer]

[He]225-mr. jackson stopped and turned away angrily to light [his]225-mr. jackson cigar . " [Women]3970-women ought to be free -- as free as [we]3970-women are , "[225-mr. jackson] [he]225-mr. jackson declared , making a discovery of which [he]225-mr. jackson was too irritated to measure the terrific consequences .

[Mr. Sillerton Jackson]225-mr. jackson stretched [his]225-mr. jackson ankles nearer the coals and emitted a sardonic whistle .

" Well , "[225-mr. jackson] [he]225-mr. jackson said after a pause , " apparently [Count Olenski]278-count olenski takes [your]225-mr. jackson view ; for [I]225-mr. jackson never heard of [his]278-count olenski having lifted a finger to get [[his]278-count olenski wife]553-his wife back . "[225-mr. jackson]

VI .

That evening , after [Mr. Jackson]225-mr. jackson had taken [himself]225-mr. jackson away , and [the ladies]735-the ladies had retired to [[their]735-the ladies chintz - curtained bedroom]970-their chintz - curtained bedroom , [Newland Archer]215-archer mounted thoughtfully to [[his]225-mr. jackson own study]971-his own study . A vigilant hand had , as usual , kept the fire alive and the lamp trimmed ; and [the room]972-the room , with [its]972-the room rows and rows of books , [its]972-the room bronze and steel statuettes of " [The Fencers]4080-the fencers "[225-mr. jackson] on the mantelpiece and [its]972-the room many photographs of famous pictures , looked singularly [home]631-home - like and welcoming .

As [he]225-mr. jackson dropped into [his]225-mr. jackson armchair near the fire [his]225-mr. jackson eyes rested on a large photograph of [May Welland]226-may , which [the young girl]790-the young girl had given [him]225-mr. jackson in the first days of [their]975-their romance , and which had now displaced all the other portraits on the table . With a new sense of awe [he]225-mr. jackson looked at the frank forehead , serious eyes and gay innocent mouth of [the young creature whose soul 's custodian [he]225-mr. jackson was to be]976-the young creature whose soul 's custodian he was to be . [That terrifying product of the social system [he]225-mr. jackson belonged to and believed in]977-that terrifying product of the social system he belonged to and believed in , [the young girl who knew nothing and expected everything]978-the young girl who knew nothing and expected everything , looked back at [him]225-mr. jackson like a stranger through [May Welland]226-may 's familiar features ; and once more it was borne in on [him]225-mr. jackson that marriage was not the safe anchorage [he]225-mr. jackson had been taught to think , but a voyage on [uncharted seas]979-uncharted seas .

The case of [the Countess Olenska]235-the countess olenska had stirred up old settled convictions and set them drifting dangerously through [his]225-mr. jackson mind . [His]225-mr. jackson own exclamation : " [Women]3970-women should be free -- as free as [we]4082-we are , "[225-mr. jackson] struck to the root of a problem that it was agreed in [his]225-mr. jackson world to regard as non - existent . " [Nice "[980-generous - minded men like himself] women]4083-nice " women , however wronged , would never claim the kind of freedom [he]225-mr. jackson meant , and [generous - minded men like [himself]225-mr. jackson]980-generous - minded men like himself were therefore -- in the heat of argument -- the more chivalrously ready to concede it to [them]980-generous - minded men like himself . Such verbal generosities were in fact only a humbugging disguise of the inexorable conventions that tied things together and bound [people]619-people down to the old pattern . But here [he]225-mr. jackson was pledged to defend , on the part of [[his]225-mr. jackson betrothed 's cousin]758-his betrothed 's cousin , conduct that , on [[his]225-mr. jackson own wife]983-his own wife 's part , would justify [him]225-mr. jackson in calling down on [her]983-his own wife all the thunders of Church and State . Of course the dilemma was purely hypothetical ; since [he]225-mr. jackson was n't [a blackguard Polish nobleman]984-a blackguard polish nobleman , it was absurd to speculate what [[his]225-mr. jackson wife]553-his wife 's rights would be if [he]225-mr. jackson WERE . But [Newland Archer]215-archer was too imaginative not to feel that , in [his]225-mr. jackson case and [May]226-may 's , the tie might gall for reasons far less gross and palpable . What could [he]225-mr. jackson and [she]226-may really know of [each other]558-each other , since it was [his]225-mr. jackson duty , as [a " decent "[987-a " decent " fellow] fellow]987-a " decent " fellow , to conceal [his]225-mr. jackson past from [her]226-may , and [hers]226-may , as [a marriageable girl]988-a marriageable girl , to have no past to conceal ? What if , for some one of the subtler reasons that would tell with both of [them]989-them , [they]989-them should tire of [each other]558-each other , misunderstand or irritate [each other]558-each other ? [He]225-mr. jackson reviewed [[his]225-mr. jackson friends]866-his friends ' marriages -- [the supposedly happy ones]993-the supposedly happy ones -- and saw none that answered , even remotely , to the passionate and tender comradeship which [he]225-mr. jackson pictured as [his]225-mr. jackson permanent relation with [May Welland]226-may . [He]225-mr. jackson perceived that such a picture presupposed , on [her]226-may part , the experience , the versatility , the freedom of judgment , which [she]226-may had been carefully trained not to possess ; and with a shiver of foreboding [he]225-mr. jackson saw [his]225-mr. jackson marriage becoming what most of the other marriages about [him]225-mr. jackson were : a dull association of material and social interests held together by ignorance on the one side and hypocrisy on the other . [Lawrence Lefferts]224-lawrence lefferts occurred to [him]225-mr. jackson as [the husband who had most completely realised this enviable ideal]994-the husband who had most completely realised this enviable ideal . As became [the high - priest of form]995-the high - priest of form , [he]225-mr. jackson had formed [a wife]996-a wife so completely to [his]225-mr. jackson own convenience that , in the most conspicuous moments of [his]225-mr. jackson frequent love - affairs with [[other men]997-other men 's wives]998-other men 's wives , [she]226-may went about in smiling unconsciousness , saying that " [Lawrence]224-lawrence lefferts was so frightfully strict "[226-may] ; and had been known to blush indignantly , and avert [her]226-may gaze , when [some one]669-some one alluded in [her]226-may presence to the fact that [Julius Beaufort]231-beaufort ( as became [a " foreigner "[226-may] of doubtful origin]1000-a " foreigner " of doubtful origin ) had what was known in [New York]2-new york as " [another establishment]4084-another establishment . "[231-beaufort]

[Archer]215-archer tried to console [himself]215-archer with the thought that [he]225-mr. jackson was not quite such an ass as [Larry Lefferts]224-lawrence lefferts , nor May such [a simpleton as [poor Gertrude]279-gertrude lefferts]1001-a simpleton as poor gertrude ; but the difference was after all one of intelligence and not of standards . In reality [they]1002-they all lived in a kind of hieroglyphic world , where the real thing was never said or done or even thought , but only represented by a set of arbitrary signs ; as when [Mrs. Welland]219-mrs. welland , who knew exactly why [Archer]215-archer had pressed [her]219-mrs. welland to announce [[her]219-mrs. welland daughter]534-her daughter 's engagement at the [Beaufort]231-beaufort ball ( and had indeed expected [him]225-mr. jackson to do no less ) , yet felt obliged to simulate reluctance , and the air of having had [her]219-mrs. welland hand forced , quite as , in the books on Primitive Man that [people of advanced culture were beginning to read]1004-people of advanced culture were beginning to read , [the savage bride]1005-the savage bride is dragged with shrieks from [[[her]1005-the savage bride parents]1006-her parents ' tent]1007-her parents ' tent .

The result , of course , was that [the young girl who was the centre of this elaborate system of mystification]1008-the young girl who was the centre of this elaborate system of mystification remained the more inscrutable for [her]1008-the young girl who was the centre of this elaborate system of mystification very frankness and assurance . [She]1008-the young girl who was the centre of this elaborate system of mystification was frank , [poor darling]1009-poor darling , because [she]1008-the young girl who was the centre of this elaborate system of mystification had nothing to conceal , assured because [she]1008-the young girl who was the centre of this elaborate system of mystification knew of nothing to be on [her]1008-the young girl who was the centre of this elaborate system of mystification guard against ; and with no better preparation than this , [she]1008-the young girl who was the centre of this elaborate system of mystification was to be plunged overnight into what [people]619-people evasively called " the facts of life . "[511-the young man]

[The young man]511-the young man was sincerely but placidly in love . [He]511-the young man delighted in the radiant good looks of [[his]511-the young man betrothed]596-his betrothed , in [her]596-his betrothed health , [her]596-his betrothed horsemanship , [her]596-his betrothed grace and quickness at games , and the shy interest in books and ideas that [she]596-his betrothed was beginning to develop under [his]511-the young man guidance . ( [She]596-his betrothed had advanced far enough to join [him]511-the young man in ridiculing the Idyls of [the King]1013-the king , but not to feel the beauty of [Ulysses]280-ulysses and [the Lotus Eaters]281-the lotus eaters . ) [She]596-his betrothed was straightforward , loyal and brave ; [she]596-his betrothed had a sense of humour ( chiefly proved by [her]596-his betrothed laughing at [HIS]511-the young man jokes ) ; and [he]511-the young man suspected , in the depths of [her]596-his betrothed innocently - gazing soul , a glow of feeling that it would be a joy to waken . But when [he]511-the young man had gone the brief round of [her]596-his betrothed [he]511-the young man returned discouraged by the thought that all this frankness and innocence were only an artificial product . Untrained human nature was not frank and innocent ; it was full of the twists and defences of an instinctive guile . And [he]511-the young man felt [himself]511-the young man oppressed by this creation of factitious purity , so cunningly manufactured by a conspiracy of [mothers]1014-mothers and [aunts]1015-aunts and [grandmothers]1016-grandmothers and [long - dead ancestresses]1017-long - dead ancestresses , because it was supposed to be what [he]511-the young man wanted , what [he]511-the young man had a right to , in order that [he]511-the young man might exercise [his]511-the young man lordly pleasure in smashing it like an image made of snow .

There was a certain triteness in these reflections : they were those habitual to [young men]930-young men on the approach of [their]930-young men wedding day . But [they]1019-they were generally accompanied by a sense of compunction and self - abasement of which [Newland Archer]215-archer felt no trace . [He]511-the young man could not deplore ( as [[Thackeray]269-thackeray 's heroes]1020-thackeray 's heroes so often exasperated [him]511-the young man by doing ) that [he]511-the young man had not a blank page to offer [[his]511-the young man bride]550-his bride in exchange for the unblemished one [she]550-his bride was to give to [him]511-the young man . [He]511-the young man could not get away from the fact that if [he]511-the young man had been brought up as [she]550-his bride had [they]1022-their would have been no more fit to find [their]1022-their way about than [the Babes in the Wood]1023-the babes in the wood ; nor could [he]511-the young man , for all [his]511-the young man anxious cogitations , see any honest reason ( any , that is , unconnected with [his]511-the young man own momentary pleasure , and the passion of masculine vanity ) why [[his]511-the young man bride]550-his bride should not have been allowed the same freedom of experience as [himself]511-the young man .

Such questions , at such an hour , were bound to drift through [his]511-the young man mind ; but [he]511-the young man was conscious that [their]1022-their uncomfortable persistence and precision were due to the inopportune arrival of [the Countess Olenska]235-the countess olenska . Here [he]511-the young man was , at the very moment of [his]511-the young man betrothal -- a moment for pure thoughts and cloudless hopes -- pitchforked into a coil of scandal which raised all the special problems [he]511-the young man would have preferred to let lie . " [Hang Ellen Olenska]233-ellen ! "[511-the young man] [he]511-the young man grumbled , as [he]511-the young man covered [his]511-the young man fire and began to undress . [He]511-the young man could not really see why [her]235-the countess olenska fate should have the least bearing on [his]511-the young man ; yet [he]511-the young man dimly felt that [he]511-the young man had only just begun to measure the risks of the championship which [his]511-the young man engagement had forced upon [him]511-the young man .

A few days later the bolt fell .

[The Lovell Mingotts]227-the mingotts had sent out cards for what was known as " a formal dinner "[227-the mingotts] ( that is , [three extra footmen]1025-three extra footmen , two dishes for each course , and a Roman punch in the middle ) , and had headed [their]1022-their invitations with the words " To meet [the Countess Olenska]235-the countess olenska , "[1022-their] in accordance with the hospitable American fashion , which treats [strangers]1026-strangers as if [they]1026-strangers were [royalties]1027-royalties , or at least as [[their]1026-strangers ambassadors]1028-their ambassadors .

[The guests]719-the guests had been selected with a boldness and discrimination in which [the initiated]600-the initiated recognised the firm hand of [Catherine the Great]237-old catherine . Associated with [such immemorial standbys as [the Selfridge Merrys]282-the selfridge merrys , who were asked everywhere because [they]282-the selfridge merrys always had been , [the Beauforts , on whom there was a claim of relationship]1032-the beauforts , on whom there was a claim of relationship , and [Mr. Sillerton Jackson]225-mr. jackson and [his]225-mr. jackson sister Sophy ( who went wherever [[her]1033-her brother]956-her brother told [her]1033-her to )]1031-such immemorial standbys as the selfridge merrys , who were asked everywhere because they always had been , the beauforts , on whom there was a claim of relationship , and mr. sillerton jackson and his sister sophy ( who went wherever her brother told her to ) , were [some of the most fashionable and yet most irreproachable of [the dominant " young married "[1036-the dominant " young married " set] set]1036-the dominant " young married " set]1035-some of the most fashionable and yet most irreproachable of the dominant " young married " set ; [the Lawrence Leffertses]283-the lawrence leffertses , [Mrs. Lefferts Rushworth]284-mrs. lefferts rushworth ( [the lovely widow]1037-the lovely widow ) , [the Harry Thorleys]228-the thorleys , [the Reggie Chiverses]285-the reggie chiverses and [young Morris Dagonet]286-young morris dagonet and [[his]286-young morris dagonet wife]553-his wife ( who was a van der [Luyden]485-dallas ) . The company indeed was perfectly assorted , since [all the members]1039-all the members belonged to [the little inner group of people who , during the long [New York]2-new york season]1040-the little inner group of people who , during the long new york season , disported [themselves]1040-the little inner group of people who , during the long new york season together daily and nightly with apparently undiminished zest .

Forty - eight hours later the unbelievable had happened ; [every one]635-every one had refused [the Mingotts]227-the mingotts ' invitation except [the Beauforts]247-the beauforts and [old Mr. Jackson]225-mr. jackson and [[his]225-mr. jackson sister]869-his sister . The intended slight was emphasised by the fact that even [the Reggie Chiverses]1043-the reggie chiverses , who were of [the Mingott clan]918-the mingott clan , were among [those inflicting it]1045-those inflicting it ; and by the uniform wording of the notes , in all of which [the writers]1046-the writers " regretted that [they]1046-the writers were unable to accept , "[1046-the writers] without the mitigating plea of a " previous engagement "[1046-the writers] that ordinary courtesy prescribed .

[New York]1047-new york society was , in those days , far too small , and too scant in [its]1048-its resources , for [every one in [it]1048-its]1049-every one in it ( including [livery - stable - keepers]1050-livery - stable - keepers , [butlers]1051-butlers and [cooks]1052-cooks ) not to know exactly on which evenings [people]619-people were free ; and it was thus possible for the recipients of [Mrs. Lovell Mingott]218-mrs. lovell mingott 's invitations to make cruelly clear [their]1054-their determination not to meet [the Countess Olenska]235-the countess olenska .

The blow was unexpected ; but [the Mingotts]227-the mingotts , as [their]1046-the writers way was , met it gallantly . [Mrs. Lovell Mingott]218-mrs. lovell mingott confided the case to [Mrs. Welland]219-mrs. welland , who confided it to [Newland Archer]215-archer ; who , aflame at the outrage , appealed passionately and authoritatively to [[his]1055-his mother]512-his mother ; who , after a painful period of inward resistance and outward temporising , succumbed to [his]1055-his instances ( as [she]512-his mother always did ) , and immediately embracing [his]1055-his cause with an energy redoubled by [her]512-his mother previous hesitations , put on [her]512-his mother grey velvet bonnet and said : " [I]512-his mother 'll go and see [Louisa van der Luyden]287-cousin louisa . "[512-his mother]

[The [New York]2-new york of [Newland Archer]215-archer]1057-the new york of newland archer 's day was [a small and slippery pyramid , in which , as yet , hardly a fissure had been made or a foothold]1058-a small and slippery pyramid , in which , as yet , hardly a fissure had been made or a foothold gained . At [its]1057-the new york of newland archer base was a firm foundation of what [Mrs. Archer]215-archer called " [plain people]4085-plain people "[215-archer] ; [an honourable but obscure majority of [respectable families who ( as in the case of [the Spicers]239-the spicers or [the Leffertses]283-the lawrence leffertses or [the Jacksons]288-the jacksons]1060-respectable families who ( as in the case of the spicers or the leffertses or the jacksons ) had been raised above [their]1059-an honourable but obscure majority of respectable families who ( as in the case of the spicers or the leffertses or the jacksons ) had been raised above their level by marriage with one of the ruling clans level by marriage with [one of [the ruling clans]1062-the ruling clans]1061-one of the ruling clans]1059-an honourable but obscure majority of respectable families who ( as in the case of the spicers or the leffertses or the jacksons ) had been raised above their level by marriage with one of the ruling clans . [People]619-people , [Mrs. Archer]215-archer always said , were not as particular as [they]619-people used to be ; and with old [Catherine Spicer]289-catherine spicer ruling [one end of [Fifth Avenue]18-fifth avenue]1064-one end of fifth avenue , and [Julius]231-beaufort Beaufort the other , [you]1065-you could n't expect the old traditions to last much longer .

Firmly narrowing upward from this wealthy but inconspicuous substratum was the compact and dominant group which [the Mingotts]227-the mingotts , [Newlands]44-newlands , [Chiverses and Mansons]1066-chiverses and mansons so actively represented . [Most people]1067-most people imagined [them]1068-them to be [the very apex of [the pyramid]1070-the pyramid]1069-the very apex of the pyramid ; but [they]1067-most people [themselves]1067-most people ( at least those of [[Mrs. Archer]215-archer 's generation]1071-mrs. archer 's generation ) were aware that , in the eyes of [the professional genealogist , only a still smaller number of families]1072-the professional genealogist , only a still smaller number of families could lay claim to that eminence .

" Do n't tell [me]215-archer , "[215-archer] [Mrs. Archer]215-archer would say to [[her]215-archer children]707-her children , " all this modern newspaper rubbish about [a [New York]2-new york aristocracy]4086-a new york aristocracy . If there is one , neither [the Mingotts]227-the mingotts nor [the Mansons]250-the mansons belong to it ; no , nor [the Newlands]44-newlands or [the Chiverses]285-the reggie chiverses either . [[Our]4087-our grandfathers]4088-our grandfathers and [great - grandfathers]4089-great - grandfathers were just [respectable English or Dutch merchants , who came to [the colonies]4091-the colonies to make [their]4090-respectable english or dutch merchants , who came to the colonies to make their fortune , and stayed here because they did so well fortune , and stayed [here]4019-here because [they]4090-respectable english or dutch merchants , who came to the colonies to make their fortune , and stayed here because they did so well did so well]4090-respectable english or dutch merchants , who came to the colonies to make their fortune , and stayed here because they did so well . [One of [[your]4094-your great - grandfathers]4095-your great - grandfathers]4093-one of your great - grandfathers signed the Declaration , and another was [a general on [Washington]242-martha 's staff]4096-a general on washington 's staff , and received [General Burgoyne]290-general burgoyne 's sword after the battle of [Saratoga]48-saratoga . These are things to be proud of , but they have nothing to do with rank or class . [New York]2-new york has always been [a commercial community]4097-a commercial community , and there are not more than [three families in [it]2-new york]4098-three families in it who can claim [an aristocratic origin in the real sense of the word]4099-an aristocratic origin in the real sense of the word . "[215-archer]

[Mrs. Archer]215-archer and [[her]215-archer son]648-her son and daughter , like [every one else in [New York]2-new york]1075-every one else in new york , knew who [these privileged beings]1076-these privileged beings were : [the Dagonets of [Washington Square]49-washington square , who came of [an old English county family allied with [the Pitts]291-the pitts and [Foxes]292-foxes]1078-an old english county family allied with the pitts and foxes]1077-the dagonets of washington square , who came of an old english county family allied with the pitts and foxes ; [the Lannings]293-the lannings , who had intermarried with [the descendants of [Count de Grasse]294-count de grasse]1079-the descendants of count de grasse , and [the van der Luydens]275-the van der luydens , [direct descendants of [the first Dutch governor of [Manhattan]50-manhattan]1081-the first dutch governor of manhattan , and related by pre - revolutionary marriages to [several members of [the French and British aristocracy]1083-the french and british aristocracy]1082-several members of the french and british aristocracy]1080-direct descendants of the first dutch governor of manhattan , and related by pre - revolutionary marriages to several members of the french and british aristocracy .

[The Lannings]293-the lannings survived only in the person of [two very old but lively [Miss Lannings]293-the lannings , who lived cheerfully and reminiscently among [family portraits]1085-family portraits and [Chippendale]51-chippendale]1084-two very old but lively miss lannings , who lived cheerfully and reminiscently among family portraits and chippendale ; [the Dagonets]295-the dagonets were [a considerable clan , allied to the best names in [Baltimore]52-baltimore and [Philadelphia]32-philadelphia]1086-a considerable clan , allied to the best names in baltimore and philadelphia ; but [the van der Luydens]275-the van der luydens , who stood above all of [them]295-the dagonets , had faded into a kind of super - terrestrial twilight , from which [only two figures impressively emerged]1087-only two figures impressively emerged ; those of [Mr.]1088-mr. and [Mrs. Henry van der Luyden]296-mrs. van der luyden .

[Mrs. Henry van der Luyden]296-mrs. van der luyden had been [Louisa Dagonet]297-louisa , and [[her]297-louisa mother]587-her mother had been [the granddaughter of [Colonel du Lac]298-colonel du lac , of [an old Channel Island family]1091-an old channel island family , who had fought under [Cornwallis]299-cornwallis and had settled in [Maryland]53-maryland , after the war , with [[his]298-colonel du lac bride]550-his bride , [Lady Angelica Trevenna]300-lady angelica trevenna , fifth daughter of [the Earl of [St. Austrey]339-st. austrey]1093-the earl of st. austrey]1090-the granddaughter of colonel du lac , of an old channel island family , who had fought under cornwallis and had settled in maryland , after the war , with his bride , lady angelica trevenna , fifth daughter of the earl of st. austrey . The tie between [the Dagonets]295-the dagonets , [the du Lacs of [Maryland]53-maryland]55-the du lacs of maryland , and [[their]295-the dagonets aristocratic [Cornish kinsfolk]1095-cornish kinsfolk]1094-their aristocratic cornish kinsfolk , [the Trevennas]301-the trevennas , had always remained close and cordial . [Mr.]1104-mr. and [Mrs. van der Luyden]296-mrs. van der luyden divided [their]1102-their time between [Trevenna]56-trevenna , [[their]1102-their place in [Maryland]53-maryland]1105-their place in maryland , and [Skuytercliff]60-skuytercliff , [the great estate on [the Hudson]61-the hudson which had been one of the colonial grants of [the Dutch government]1107-the dutch government]1106-the great estate on the hudson which had been one of the colonial grants of the dutch government to [the famous first Governor]1108-the famous first governor , and of which [Mr. van der Luyden]302-mr. van der luyden was still " [Patroon]350-patroon . "[1102-their] [[Their]1102-their large solemn house in [Madison Avenue]63-madison avenue]1109-their large solemn house in madison avenue was seldom opened , and when [they]1102-their came to [town]1110-town [they]1102-their received in [it]1109-their large solemn house in madison avenue only [[their]1102-their most intimate friends]1111-their most intimate friends .

" [I]512-his mother wish [you]302-mr. van der luyden would go with [me]512-his mother , [Newland]215-archer , "[512-his mother] [[his]302-mr. van der luyden mother]512-his mother said , suddenly pausing at the door of [the Brown coupe]1113-the brown coupe . "[512-his mother]

VII .

[Mrs. Henry van der Luyden]296-mrs. van der luyden listened in silence to [[her]296-mrs. van der luyden cousin]672-her cousin [Mrs. Archer]215-archer 's narrative .

It was all very well to tell [yourself]1115-yourself in advance that [Mrs. van der Luyden]296-mrs. van der luyden was always silent , and that , though non - committal by nature and training , [she]296-mrs. van der luyden was very kind to [the people [she]296-mrs. van der luyden really liked]1116-the people she really liked . Even personal experience of these facts was not always a protection from the chill that descended on one in [the high - ceilinged white - walled [Madison Avenue drawing - room]1118-madison avenue drawing - room]1117-the high - ceilinged white - walled madison avenue drawing - room , with the pale brocaded armchairs so obviously uncovered for the occasion , and the gauze still veiling the ormolu mantel ornaments and the beautiful old carved frame of [Gainsborough]303-gainsborough 's " [Lady Angelica du Lac]304-lady angelica du lac . "[1119-her lovely ancestress]

[Mrs. van der Luyden]296-mrs. van der luyden 's portrait by [Huntington]305-huntington ( in black velvet and Venetian point ) faced that of [[her]296-mrs. van der luyden lovely ancestress]1119-her lovely ancestress . It was generally considered " as fine as a Cabanel , "[1119-her lovely ancestress] and , though twenty years had elapsed since its execution , was still " a perfect likeness . "[1119-her lovely ancestress] Indeed the [Mrs. van der Luyden]296-mrs. van der luyden who sat beneath [it]1120-it listening to [Mrs. Archer]215-archer might have been [the twin - sister of [the fair and still youngish woman drooping against a gilt armchair before a green rep curtain]1122-the fair and still youngish woman drooping against a gilt armchair before a green rep curtain]1121-the twin - sister of the fair and still youngish woman drooping against a gilt armchair before a green rep curtain . [Mrs. van der Luyden]296-mrs. van der luyden still wore black velvet and Venetian point when [she]296-mrs. van der luyden went into society -- or rather ( since [she]296-mrs. van der luyden never dined out ) when [she]296-mrs. van der luyden threw open [her]296-mrs. van der luyden own doors to receive it . [Her]296-mrs. van der luyden fair hair , which had faded without turning grey , was still parted in flat overlapping points on [her]296-mrs. van der luyden forehead , and the straight nose that divided [her]296-mrs. van der luyden pale blue eyes was only a little more pinched about the nostrils than when the portrait had been painted . [She]296-mrs. van der luyden always , indeed , struck [Newland Archer]215-archer as having been rather gruesomely preserved in the airless atmosphere of a perfectly irreproachable existence , as bodies caught in glaciers keep for years a rosy life - in - death .

Like all [[his]1123-his family]1124-his family , [he]1123-his esteemed and admired [Mrs. van der Luyden]296-mrs. van der luyden ; but [he]1123-his found [her]296-mrs. van der luyden gentle bending sweetness less approachable than the grimness of [some of [[his]1123-his mother 's old aunts]1126-his mother 's old aunts]1125-some of his mother 's old aunts , [fierce spinsters who said " No "[1127-fierce spinsters who said " no " on principle before they knew what they were going to be asked] on principle before [they]1125-some of his mother 's old aunts knew what [they]1125-some of his mother 's old aunts were going to be asked]1127-fierce spinsters who said " no " on principle before they knew what they were going to be asked .

[Mrs. van der Luyden]296-mrs. van der luyden 's attitude said neither yes nor no , but always appeared to incline to clemency till [her]296-mrs. van der luyden thin lips , wavering into the shadow of a smile , made the almost invariable reply : " [I]296-mrs. van der luyden shall first have to talk this over with [[my]296-mrs. van der luyden husband]4101-my husband . "[296-mrs. van der luyden]

[She]296-mrs. van der luyden and [Mr. van der Luyden]302-mr. van der luyden were so exactly alike that [Archer]215-archer often wondered how , after forty years of the closest conjugality , two such merged identities ever separated [themselves]1128-themselves enough for anything as controversial as a talking - over . [VIII]313-viii .

It was generally agreed in [New York]2-new york that [the Countess Olenska]235-the countess olenska had " lost [her]235-the countess olenska looks . "[235-the countess olenska]

[She]235-the countess olenska had appeared [there]713-there first , in [[Newland Archer]215-archer 's boyhood]1171-newland archer 's boyhood , as [a brilliantly pretty little girl of nine or ten]1172-a brilliantly pretty little girl of nine or ten , of whom [people]619-people said that [she]235-the countess olenska " ought to be painted . "[619-people] [[Her]235-the countess olenska parents]1006-her parents had been [continental wanderers]1175-continental wanderers , and after a roaming babyhood [she]235-the countess olenska had lost [them]1006-her parents both , and been taken in charge by [[her]235-the countess olenska aunt]1176-her aunt , [Medora Manson]230-medora manson , also [a wanderer , who was [herself]230-medora manson returning to [New York]2-new york to " settle down]4131-a wanderer , who was herself returning to new york to " settle down . "[4131-a wanderer , who was herself returning to new york to " settle down]

[Poor Medora]314-poor medora , repeatedly widowed , was always coming [home]631-home to settle down ( each time in [a less expensive house]1178-a less expensive house ) , and bringing with [her]230-medora manson [a new husband]1179-a new husband or [an adopted child]1180-an adopted child ; but after a few months [she]230-medora manson invariably parted from [[her]230-medora manson husband]645-her husband or quarrelled with [[her]230-medora manson ward]1182-her ward , and , having got rid of [[her]230-medora manson house]800-her house at a loss , set out again on [her]230-medora manson wanderings . As [[her]235-the countess olenska mother]587-her mother had been [a Rushworth]284-mrs. lefferts rushworth , and [her]235-the countess olenska last unhappy marriage had linked [her]235-the countess olenska to one of [the crazy Chiverses]1185-the crazy chiverses , [New York]2-new york looked indulgently on [her]235-the countess olenska eccentricities ; but when [she]235-the countess olenska returned with [[her]235-the countess olenska little orphaned niece]1186-her little orphaned niece , whose parents had been popular in spite of [their]1187-their regrettable taste for travel , [people]619-people thought it a pity that [the pretty child]1189-the pretty child should be in such hands .

[Every one]635-every one was disposed to be kind to [little Ellen Mingott]261-ellen , though [her]235-the countess olenska dusky red cheeks and tight curls gave [her]235-the countess olenska an air of gaiety that seemed unsuitable in [a child who should still have been in black for [[her]235-the countess olenska parents]1006-her parents]1191-a child who should still have been in black for her parents . It was one of the misguided [Medora]230-medora manson 's many peculiarities to flout the unalterable rules that regulated American mourning , and when [she]235-the countess olenska stepped from the steamer [[her]235-the countess olenska family]1193-her family were scandalised to see that the crape veil [she]235-the countess olenska wore for [[her]235-the countess olenska own brother]1194-her own brother was seven inches shorter than those of [[her]235-the countess olenska sisters - in - law]1195-her sisters - in - law , while [little Ellen]261-ellen was in crimson merino and amber beads , like a gipsy foundling .

But [New York]2-new york had so long resigned itself to [Medora]230-medora manson that [only a few old ladies]1196-only a few old ladies shook [their]1196-only a few old ladies heads over [Ellen]261-ellen 's gaudy clothes , while [[her]261-ellen other relations]1197-her other relations fell under the charm of [her]261-ellen high colour and high spirits . [She]261-ellen was a fearless and familiar little thing , who asked disconcerting questions , made precocious comments , and possessed outlandish arts , such as dancing a Spanish shawl dance and singing Neapolitan love - songs to a guitar . Under the direction of [[her]261-ellen aunt]1176-her aunt ( whose real name was [Mrs. Thorley Chivers]315-mrs. thorley chivers , but who , having received a Papal title , had resumed [[her]1176-her aunt first husband]1199-her first husband 's patronymic , and called [herself]1176-her aunt [the Marchioness Manson]316-the marchioness manson , because in [Italy]65-italy [she]1176-her aunt could turn it into [Manzoni]66-manzoni ) [the little girl]1200-the little girl received an expensive but incoherent education , which included " drawing from [the model]4132-the model , "[1200-the little girl] a thing never dreamed of before , and playing the piano in quintets with [professional musicians]1201-professional musicians .

Of course no good could come of this ; and when , a few years later , [poor Chivers]315-mrs. thorley chivers finally died in [a madhouse]1202-a madhouse , [[his]1199-her first husband widow]1203-his widow ( draped in strange weeds ) again pulled up stakes and departed with [Ellen]261-ellen , who had grown into [a tall bony girl with conspicuous eyes]1204-a tall bony girl with conspicuous eyes . For some time no more was heard of [them]1205-them ; then news came of [Ellen]261-ellen 's marriage to [an immensely rich Polish nobleman of legendary fame , whom [she]261-ellen had met at a ball at [the Tuileries]29-the tuileries]1206-an immensely rich polish nobleman of legendary fame , whom she had met at a ball at the tuileries , and who was said to have [princely establishments in [Paris]7-paris , [Nice]24-nice and [Florence]67-florence]1207-princely establishments in paris , nice and florence , [a yacht at [Cowes]68-cowes , and many square miles of shooting in [Transylvania]69-transylvania]1208-a yacht at cowes , and many square miles of shooting in transylvania . [She]261-ellen disappeared in a kind of sulphurous apotheosis , and when a few years later [Medora]230-medora manson again came back to [New York]2-new york , subdued , impoverished , mourning [a third husband]1209-a third husband , and in quest of [a still smaller house]1210-a still smaller house , [people]619-people wondered that [[her]230-medora manson rich niece]1212-her rich niece had not been able to do something for [her]230-medora manson . Then came the news that [Ellen]261-ellen 's own marriage had ended in disaster , and that [she]261-ellen was [herself]261-ellen returning [home]631-home to seek rest and oblivion among [[her]261-ellen kinsfolk]1214-her kinsfolk .

These things passed through [Newland Archer]215-archer 's mind a week later as [he]1215-he watched [the Countess Olenska]235-the countess olenska enter [the van der Luyden drawing - room]1216-the van der luyden drawing - room on the evening of the momentous dinner . The occasion was a solemn one , and [he]1215-he wondered a little nervously how [she]235-the countess olenska would carry it off . [She]235-the countess olenska came rather late , one hand still ungloved , and fastening a bracelet about [her]235-the countess olenska wrist ; yet [she]235-the countess olenska entered without any appearance of haste or embarrassment [the drawing - room in which [New York]2-new york 's most chosen company]1217-the drawing - room in which new york 's most chosen company was somewhat awfully assembled .

In the middle of [the room]972-the room [she]235-the countess olenska paused , looking about [her]235-the countess olenska with a grave mouth and smiling eyes ; and in that instant [Newland Archer]215-archer rejected the general verdict on [her]235-the countess olenska looks . It was true that [her]235-the countess olenska early radiance was gone . The red cheeks had paled ; [she]235-the countess olenska was thin , worn , a little older - looking than [her]235-the countess olenska age , which must have been nearly thirty . But there was about [her]235-the countess olenska the mysterious authority of beauty , a sureness in the carriage of the head , the movement of the eyes , which , without being in the least theatrical , struck [his]1215-he as highly trained and full of a conscious power . At the same time [she]235-the countess olenska was simpler in manner than [most of [the ladies present]1220-the ladies present]1219-most of the ladies present , and [many people]1221-many people ( as [he]1215-he heard afterward from [Janey]264-janey ) were disappointed that [her]235-the countess olenska appearance was not more " stylish"--for[235-the countess olenska] stylishness was what [New York]2-new york most valued . It was , perhaps , [Archer]264-janey reflected , because [her]235-the countess olenska early vivacity had disappeared ; because [she]235-the countess olenska was so quiet -- quiet in [her]235-the countess olenska movements , [her]235-the countess olenska voice , and the tones of [her]235-the countess olenska low - pitched voice . [New York]2-new york had expected something a good deal more reasonant in [a young woman with such a history]1222-a young woman with such a history .

The dinner was a somewhat formidable business . Dining with [the van der Luydens]275-the van der luydens was at best no light matter , and dining [there]713-there with [a Duke who was [[their]1225-they cousin]1165-their cousin]1224-a duke who was their cousin was almost a religious solemnity . It pleased [Archer]264-janey to think that [only an old New Yorker]1227-only an old new yorker could perceive the shade of difference ( to [New York]2-new york ) between being merely [a Duke]1228-a duke and being [[the van der Luydens]275-the van der luydens ' Duke]1229-the van der luydens ' duke . [New York]2-new york took [stray noblemen]1230-stray noblemen calmly , and even ( except in [the Struthers set ) with a certain distrustful hauteur]1231-the struthers set ) with a certain distrustful hauteur ; but when [they]1225-they presented such credentials as these [they]1225-they were received with an old - fashioned cordiality that [they]1225-they would have been greatly mistaken in ascribing solely to [their]1225-they standing in [Debrett]70-debrett . It was for just such distinctions that [the young man]511-the young man cherished [his]511-the young man old [New York]2-new york even while [he]511-the young man smiled at it .

[The van der Luydens]275-the van der luydens had done [their]275-the van der luydens best to emphasise the importance of the occasion . The du Lac Sevres and the Trevenna George II plate were out ; so was [the van der [Luyden]485-dallas " Lowestoft "[275-the van der luydens] ( [East India]72-east india [Company]73-company]71-the van der luyden " lowestoft " ( east india company ) and [the Dagonet Crown Derby]1233-the dagonet crown derby . [The Countess Olenska]235-the countess olenska was [the only young woman at the dinner]1241-the only young woman at the dinner ; yet , as [Archer]215-archer scanned the smooth plump elderly faces between [their]735-the ladies diamond necklaces and towering ostrich feathers , [they]735-the ladies struck [him]648-her son as curiously immature compared with [hers]235-the countess olenska . [The Duke of [St. Austrey]339-st. austrey , who sat at [[his]1242-the duke of st. austrey , who sat at his hostess 's right hostess]1243-his hostess 's right]1242-the duke of st. austrey , who sat at his hostess 's right , was naturally [the chief figure of the evening]1244-the chief figure of the evening . It was not the custom in [[New York]2-new york drawing - rooms]1260-new york drawing - rooms for [a lady]680-a lady to get up and walk away from [one gentleman]1262-one gentleman in order to seek the company of another . Etiquette required that [she]1255-the countess should wait , immovable as [an idol]710-an idol , while [the men who wished to converse with [her]1255-the countess]1264-the men who wished to converse with her succeeded each other at [her]1255-the countess side . [[Madame Olenska]241-madame olenska 's own dwelling]1297-madame olenska 's own dwelling was redeemed from the same appearance only by a little more paint about the window - frames ; and as [Archer]215-archer mustered [its]1297-madame olenska 's own dwelling modest front [he]574-the latter said to [himself]574-the latter that [the Polish Count]1298-the polish count must have robbed [her]241-madame olenska of [her]241-madame olenska fortune as well as of [her]241-madame olenska illusions .

[The young man]511-the young man had spent an unsatisfactory day . [He]511-the young man wanted to have [her]226-may to [himself]511-the young man , to tell [her]226-may how enchanting [she]226-may had looked the night before , and how proud [he]511-the young man was of [her]226-may , and to press [her]226-may to hasten [their]1302-their marriage . But [Mrs. Welland]219-mrs. welland had firmly reminded [him]511-the young man that the round of family visits was not half over , and , when [he]511-the young man hinted at advancing the date of the wedding , had raised reproachful eye - brows and sighed out : " Twelve dozen of everything -- hand - embroidered-- "[511-the young man]

Packed in [the family]532-the family landau [they]1304-they rolled from [one tribal doorstep]1305-one tribal doorstep to another , and [Archer]215-archer , when the afternoon 's round was over , parted from [[his]511-the young man betrothed]596-his betrothed with the feeling that [he]511-the young man had been shown off like a wild animal cunningly trapped . " Tomorrow , "[219-mrs. welland] [Mrs. Welland]219-mrs. welland called after [him]511-the young man , " [we]1307-their 'll do [the Chiverses]285-the reggie chiverses and [the Dallases]324-the dallases "[219-mrs. welland] ; and [he]511-the young man perceived that [she]219-mrs. welland was going through [[their]1307-their two families]1308-their two families alphabetically , and that [they]1307-their were only in the first quarter of the alphabet .

[He]511-the young man had meant to tell [May]226-may of [the Countess Olenska]235-the countess olenska 's request -- [her]219-mrs. welland command , rather -- that [he]511-the young man should call on [her]219-mrs. welland that afternoon ; but in the brief moments when [they]1307-their were alone [he]511-the young man had had more pressing things to say . Besides , it struck [him]511-the young man as a little absurd to allude to the matter . [He]511-the young man knew that [May]226-may most particularly wanted [him]511-the young man to be kind to [[her]226-may cousin]672-her cousin ; was it not that wish which had hastened the announcement of [their]1307-their engagement ? It gave [him]511-the young man an odd sensation to reflect that , but for [the Countess]1255-the countess 's arrival , [he]511-the young man might have been , if not still [a free man]1311-a free man , at least [a man less irrevocably pledged]1312-a man less irrevocably pledged . As [he]511-the young man stood on [Madame Olenska]241-madame olenska 's threshold curiosity was [his]511-the young man uppermost feeling . [He]511-the young man was puzzled by the tone in which [she]241-madame olenska had summoned [him]511-the young man ; [he]511-the young man concluded that [she]241-madame olenska was less simple than [she]241-madame olenska seemed .

The door was opened by [a swarthy foreign - looking maid]1314-a swarthy foreign - looking maid , with a prominent bosom under a gay neckerchief , whom [he]511-the young man vaguely fancied to be [Sicilian]1315-sicilian . [She]1314-a swarthy foreign - looking maid welcomed [him]511-the young man with all [her]1314-a swarthy foreign - looking maid white teeth , and answering [his]511-the young man enquiries by a head - shake of incomprehension led [him]511-the young man through [the narrow hall]1316-the narrow hall into [a low firelit drawing - room]1317-a low firelit drawing - room . [The room]972-the room was empty , and [she]1314-a swarthy foreign - looking maid left [him]511-the young man , for an appreciable time , to wonder whether [she]1314-a swarthy foreign - looking maid had gone to find [[her]1314-a swarthy foreign - looking maid mistress]1319-her mistress , or whether [she]1314-a swarthy foreign - looking maid had not understood what [he]511-the young man was there for , and thought it might be to wind the clock -- of which [he]511-the young man perceived that the only visible specimen had stopped . [He]511-the young man knew that [the southern races]1320-the southern races communicated with each other in the language of pantomime , and was mortified to find [her]1314-a swarthy foreign - looking maid shrugs and smiles so unintelligible . At length [she]1314-a swarthy foreign - looking maid returned with a lamp ; and [Archer]215-archer , having meanwhile put together a phrase out of [Dante]325-dante and [Petrarch]326-petrarch , evoked the answer : " La signora e fuori ; ma verra subito "[215-archer] ; which [he]511-the young man took to mean : " [She]1314-a swarthy foreign - looking maid 's out -- but [you]4157-you 'll soon see . "[215-archer]

What [he]511-the young man saw , meanwhile , with the help of the lamp , was the faded shadowy charm of [a room unlike [any room [he]511-the young man had known]1322-any room he had known]1321-a room unlike any room he had known . [He]511-the young man knew that [the Countess Olenska]235-the countess olenska had brought some of [her]235-the countess olenska possessions with [her]235-the countess olenska -- bits of wreckage , [she]235-the countess olenska called them -- and these , [he]511-the young man supposed , were represented by some small slender tables of dark wood , a delicate little Greek bronze on the chimney - piece , and a stretch of red damask nailed on the discoloured wallpaper behind a couple of Italian - looking pictures in old frames .

[Newland Archer]215-archer prided [himself]511-the young man on [his]511-the young man knowledge of Italian art . [[His]511-the young man boyhood]857-his boyhood had been saturated with [Ruskin]327-ruskin , and [he]511-the young man had read all the latest books : [John Addington Symonds]328-john addington symonds , [Vernon Lee]329-vernon lee 's " [Euphorion]330-euphorion , "[328-john addington symonds] the essays of [P. G. Hamerton]331-p. g. hamerton , and a wonderful new volume called " The Renaissance "[332-walter pater] by [Walter Pater]332-walter pater . [He]511-the young man talked easily of [Botticelli]333-botticelli , and spoke of [Fra Angelico]334-fra angelico with a faint condescension . But these pictures bewildered [him]511-the young man , for they were like nothing that [he]511-the young man was accustomed to look at ( and therefore able to see ) when [he]511-the young man travelled in [Italy]65-italy ; and perhaps , also , [his]511-the young man powers of observation were impaired by the oddness of finding [himself]511-the young man in [this strange empty house]1324-this strange empty house , where apparently [no one]601-no one expected [him]511-the young man . [He]511-the young man was sorry that [he]511-the young man had not told [May Welland]226-may of [Countess Olenska]235-the countess olenska 's request , and a little disturbed by the thought that [[his]511-the young man betrothed]596-his betrothed might come in to see [[her]596-his betrothed cousin]672-her cousin . What would [she]596-his betrothed think if [she]596-his betrothed found [him]511-the young man sitting there with the air of intimacy implied by waiting alone in the dusk at [[a lady]680-a lady 's fireside]1329-a lady 's fireside ?

But since [he]511-the young man had come [he]511-the young man meant to wait ; and [he]511-the young man sank into a chair and stretched [his]511-the young man feet to the logs .

It was odd to have summoned [him]511-the young man in that way , and then forgotten [him]511-the young man ; but [Archer]215-archer felt more curious than mortified . The atmosphere of [the room]972-the room was so different from any [he]511-the young man had ever breathed that self - consciousness vanished in the sense of adventure . [He]511-the young man had been before in [drawing - rooms hung with red damask]1331-drawing - rooms hung with red damask , with pictures " of [the Italian school]4158-the italian school "[511-the young man] ; what struck [him]511-the young man was the way in which [[Medora Manson]230-medora manson 's shabby hired house]1332-medora manson 's shabby hired house , with [its]1332-medora manson 's shabby hired house blighted background of pampas grass and Rogers statuettes , had , by a turn of the hand , and the skilful use of [a few properties]1333-a few properties , been transformed into something intimate , " foreign , "[511-the young man] subtly suggestive of old romantic scenes and sentiments . [He]511-the young man tried to analyse the trick , to find a clue to it in the way the chairs and tables were grouped , in the fact that only two Jacqueminot roses ( of which [nobody]3966-nobody ever bought less than a dozen ) had been placed in the slender vase at [his]511-the young man elbow , and in the vague pervading perfume that was not what [one]503-one put on handkerchiefs , but rather like the scent of [some far - off bazaar]1336-some far - off bazaar , a smell made up of Turkish coffee and ambergris and dried roses .

[His]511-the young man mind wandered away to the question of what [[May]226-may 's drawing - room]1337-may 's drawing - room would look like . [He]511-the young man knew that [Mr. Welland]335-mr. welland , who was behaving " very handsomely , "[335-mr. welland] already had [his]335-mr. welland eye on [a newly built house in [East Thirty - ninth Street]77-east thirty - ninth street]1338-a newly built house in east thirty - ninth street . [The neighbourhood]1339-the neighbourhood was thought remote , and [the house]516-the house was built in a ghastly greenish - yellow stone that [the younger architects]1341-the younger architects were beginning to employ as a protest against the brownstone of which the uniform hue coated [New York]2-new york like a cold chocolate sauce ; but the plumbing was perfect . [Archer]215-archer would have liked to travel , to put off the housing question ; but , though [the Wellands]321-the wellands approved of an extended European honeymoon ( perhaps even a winter in [Egypt]78-egypt ) , [they]321-the wellands were firm as to the need of [a house for [the returning couple]1343-the returning couple]1342-a house for the returning couple . [The young man]511-the young man felt that [his]511-the young man fate was sealed : for the rest of [his]511-the young man life [he]511-the young man would go up every evening between the cast - iron railings of [that greenish - yellow doorstep]1345-that greenish - yellow doorstep , and pass through [a Pompeian vestibule]1346-a pompeian vestibule into [a hall]1347-a hall with a wainscoting of varnished yellow wood . But beyond that [his]511-the young man imagination could not travel . [He]511-the young man knew [the drawing - room above]1348-the drawing - room above had a bay window , but [he]511-the young man could not fancy how [May]1349-may would deal with [it]1350-it . [She]1349-may submitted cheerfully to the purple satin and yellow tuftings of [the Welland drawing - room]1351-the welland drawing - room , to [its]1351-the welland drawing - room sham Buhl tables and gilt vitrines full of modern Saxe . [The round - bosomed maid]1354-the round - bosomed maid came in , drew the curtains , pushed back a log , and said consolingly : " Verra -- verra . "[1354-the round - bosomed maid] When [she]1354-the round - bosomed maid had gone [Archer]215-archer stood up and began to wander about . Should [he]511-the young man wait any longer ? [His]511-the young man position was becoming rather foolish . Perhaps [he]511-the young man had misunderstood [Madame Olenska]241-madame olenska -- perhaps [she]1349-may had not invited [him]511-the young man after all .

Down the cobblestones of [the quiet street]1355-the quiet street came the ring of [a stepper]1356-a stepper 's hoofs ; [they]1357-they stopped before [the house]516-the house , and [he]511-the young man caught the opening of a carriage door . [The Duke]339-st. austrey said " Rather "[339-st. austrey] from the depths of [his]339-st. austrey beard , and [Archer]256-archer withdrew with a stiffly circular bow that made [him]256-archer feel as full of spine as [a self - conscious school - boy among [careless and unnoticing elders]1389-careless and unnoticing elders]1388-a self - conscious school - boy among careless and unnoticing elders .

[He]256-archer was not sorry for the denouement of [his]256-archer visit : [he]256-archer only wished it had come sooner , and spared [him]256-archer a certain waste of emotion . As [he]256-archer went out into the wintry night , [New York]2-new york again became vast and imminent , and [May Welland]226-may [the loveliest woman in it]1390-the loveliest woman in it . As [he]256-archer wrote a word on [his]256-archer card and waited for an envelope [he]256-archer glanced about [the embowered shop]1393-the embowered shop , and [his]256-archer eye lit on a cluster of yellow roses . [He]256-archer had never seen any as sun - golden before , and [his]256-archer first impulse was to send them to [May]226-may instead of the lilies . But they did not look like [her]226-may -- there was something too rich , too strong , in their fiery beauty . In a sudden revulsion of mood , and almost without knowing what [he]256-archer did , [he]256-archer signed to [the florist]1394-the florist to lay the roses in another long box , and slipped [his]256-archer card into a second envelope , on which [he]256-archer wrote the name of [the Countess Olenska]235-the countess olenska ; then , just as [he]256-archer was turning away , [he]256-archer drew the card out again , and left the empty envelope on the box .

" [They]4218-they 'll go at once ? "[256-archer] [he]256-archer enquired , pointing to the roses .

[The florist]1394-the florist assured [him]256-archer that they would .

[X.]341-x.

The next day [he]256-archer persuaded [May]226-may to escape for a walk in [the Park]1301-the park after luncheon . As was the custom in old - fashioned Episcopalian [New York]2-new york , [she]226-may usually accompanied [[her]226-may parents]1006-her parents to [church]1398-church on Sunday afternoons ; but [Mrs. Welland]219-mrs. welland condoned [her]226-may truancy , having that very morning won [her]226-may over to the necessity of a long engagement , with time to prepare a hand - embroidered trousseau containing the proper number of dozens .

The day was delectable . The bare vaulting of trees along [the Mall]1399-the mall was ceiled with lapis lazuli , and arched above snow that shone like splintered crystals . It was the weather to call out [May]226-may 's radiance , and [she]226-may burned like a young maple in the frost . [Archer]256-archer was proud of the glances turned on [her]226-may , and the simple joy of [possessorship]1400-possessorship cleared away [his]256-archer underlying perplexities .

" It 's so delicious -- waking every morning to smell lilies - of - [the - valley]549-the - valley in [one 's room]4220-one 's room ! "[226-may] [she]226-may said .

[XI]351-xi .

[Archer]264-janey felt [his]264-janey temper rising . " [[Her]226-may uncles]4321-her uncles ought to deal with this , "[264-janey] [he]264-janey said .

" Will [you]256-archer oblige [me]511-the young man , [Mr. Archer]256-archer , by first looking through these papers ? Afterward , when [we]1482-them have talked the case over , [I]511-the young man will give [you]256-archer [my]511-the young man opinion . "[511-the young man]

[Archer]256-archer withdrew reluctantly with the unwelcome documents . Since [their]1482-them last meeting [he]256-archer had half - unconsciously collaborated with events in ridding [himself]256-archer of the burden of [Madame Olenska]241-madame olenska . [His]256-archer hour alone with [her]241-madame olenska by the firelight had drawn [them]1482-them into a momentary intimacy on which [the Duke of St. Austrey]339-st. austrey 's intrusion with [Mrs. Lemuel Struthers]260-mrs. struthers , and [the Countess]1255-the countess 's joyous greeting of [them]1482-them , had rather providentially broken . Two days later [Archer]256-archer had assisted at the comedy of [her]241-madame olenska reinstatement in [the van der Luydens]275-the van der luydens ' favour , and had said to [himself]256-archer , with a touch of tartness , that [a lady who knew how to thank all - powerful elderly gentlemen to such good purpose for a bunch of flowers]1484-a lady who knew how to thank all - powerful elderly gentlemen to such good purpose for a bunch of flowers did not need either the private consolations or the public championship of [a young man of [his]256-archer small compass]1485-a young man of his small compass . To look at the matter in this light simplified [his]256-archer own case and surprisingly furbished up all the dim domestic virtues . [He]256-archer could not picture [May Welland]226-may , in whatever conceivable emergency , hawking about [her]226-may private difficulties and lavishing [her]226-may confidences on [strange men]1486-strange men ; and [she]226-may had never seemed to [him]256-archer finer or fairer than in the week that followed . [He]256-archer had even yielded to [her]226-may wish for a long engagement , since [she]226-may had found the one disarming answer to [his]256-archer plea for haste .

" [You]226-may know , when it comes to the point , [[your]226-may parents]4324-your parents have always let [you]226-may have [your]226-may way ever since [you]226-may were [a little girl]4325-a little girl , "[256-archer] [he]256-archer argued ; and [she]226-may had answered , with [her]226-may clearest look : " Yes ; and that 's what makes it so hard to refuse the very last thing [they]4324-your parents 'll ever ask of [me]226-may as [a little girl]4325-a little girl . "[226-may]

That was the old [New York]2-new york note ; that was the kind of answer [he]256-archer would like always to be sure of [[his]256-archer wife]553-his wife 's making . If one had habitually breathed the [New York]2-new york air there were times when anything less crystalline seemed stifling .

The papers [he]256-archer had retired to read did not tell [him]256-archer much in fact ; but they plunged [him]256-archer into an atmosphere in which [he]256-archer choked and spluttered . They consisted mainly of an exchange of letters between [[Count Olenski]278-count olenski 's solicitors]1488-count olenski 's solicitors and [a French legal firm to whom [the Countess]1255-the countess had applied for the settlement of [her]1255-the countess financial situation]1489-a french legal firm to whom the countess had applied for the settlement of her financial situation . There was also a short letter from [the Count]1491-the count to [[his]1491-the count wife]553-his wife : after reading it , [Newland Archer]215-archer rose , jammed the papers back into [their]1493-their envelope , and reentered [[Mr. Letterblair]353-mr. letterblair 's office]1494-mr. letterblair 's office .

" Here are the letters , [sir]4062-sir . If [you]4062-sir wish , [I]256-archer 'll see [Madame Olenska]241-madame olenska , "[256-archer] [he]256-archer said in a constrained voice .

" Thank [you]4062-sir -- thank [you]4062-sir , [Mr. Archer]256-archer . Come and dine with [me]256-archer tonight if [you]4062-sir 're free , and [we]4328-we 'll go into the matter afterward : in case [you]4062-sir wish to call on [[our]4328-we client]4329-our client tomorrow . "[256-archer]

[Newland Archer]215-archer walked straight [home]631-home again that afternoon . It was a winter evening of transparent clearness , with an innocent young moon above [the house - tops]1496-the house - tops ; and [he]256-archer wanted to fill [his]256-archer soul 's lungs with the pure radiance , and not exchange a word with [any one]1132-any one till [he]256-archer and [Mr. Letterblair]353-mr. letterblair were closeted together after dinner . It was impossible to decide otherwise than [he]256-archer had done : [he]256-archer must see [Madame Olenska]241-madame olenska [himself]256-archer rather than let [her]241-madame olenska secrets be bared to other eyes . A great wave of compassion had swept away [his]256-archer indifference and impatience : [she]241-madame olenska stood before [him]256-archer as an exposed and pitiful figure , to be saved at all costs from farther wounding [herself]241-madame olenska in [her]241-madame olenska mad plunges against fate .

[He]256-archer remembered what [she]241-madame olenska had told [him]256-archer of [Mrs. Welland]219-mrs. welland 's request to be spared whatever was " unpleasant "[241-madame olenska] in [her]241-madame olenska history , and winced at the thought that it was perhaps this attitude of mind which kept the [New York]2-new york air so pure . " Are [we]4330-we only [Pharisees]4331-pharisees after all ? "[256-archer] [he]256-archer wondered , puzzled by the effort to reconcile [his]256-archer instinctive disgust at human vileness with [his]256-archer equally instinctive pity for human frailty .

For the first time [he]256-archer perceived how elementary [his]256-archer own principles had always been . [He]256-archer passed for [a young man who had not been afraid of risks]1498-a young man who had not been afraid of risks , and [he]256-archer knew that [his]256-archer secret love - affair with poor silly [Mrs. Thorley Rushworth]243-mrs. thorley rushworth had not been too secret to invest [him]256-archer with a becoming air of adventure . But [Mrs. Rushworth]243-mrs. thorley rushworth was " [that kind of woman]4332-that kind of woman "[243-mrs. thorley rushworth] ; foolish , vain , clandestine by nature , and far more attracted by the secrecy and peril of the affair than by such charms and qualities as [he]256-archer possessed . When the fact dawned on [him]256-archer it nearly broke [his]256-archer heart , but now it seemed the redeeming feature of the case . The affair , in short , had been of the kind that [most of [the young men of]1500-the young men of [his]256-archer age]1499-most of the young men of his age had been through , and emerged from with calm consciences and an undisturbed belief in the abysmal distinction between [the women [one loved and respected]1502-one loved and respected and those [one]503-one enjoyed -- and pitied]1501-the women one loved and respected and those one enjoyed -- and pitied . In this view [they]1500-the young men of were sedulously abetted by [[their]1500-the young men of mothers]1504-their mothers , [aunts]1015-aunts and [other elderly female relatives]1506-other elderly female relatives , who all shared [Mrs. Archer]215-archer 's belief that when " such things happened "[1507-the man] it was undoubtedly foolish of [the man]1507-the man , but somehow always criminal of [the woman]4020-the woman . [All the elderly ladies whom [Archer]215-archer knew]1509-all the elderly ladies whom archer knew regarded [any woman who loved imprudently]1510-any woman who loved imprudently as necessarily unscrupulous and designing , and [mere simple - minded man]1511-mere simple - minded man as powerless in [her]4020-the woman clutches . The only thing to do was to persuade [him]256-archer , as early as possible , to marry [a nice girl]1512-a nice girl , and then trust to [her]1512-a nice girl to look after [him]256-archer .

In the complicated old European communities , [Archer]215-archer began to guess , love - problems might be less simple and less easily classified . [Rich and idle and ornamental societies]1513-rich and idle and ornamental societies must produce many more such situations ; and there might even be one in which [a woman naturally sensitive and aloof]1514-a woman naturally sensitive and aloof would yet , from the force of circumstances , from sheer defencelessness and loneliness , be drawn into a tie inexcusable by conventional standards .

On reaching [home]631-home [he]256-archer wrote a line to [the Countess Olenska]235-the countess olenska , asking at what hour of the next day [she]235-the countess olenska could receive [him]256-archer , and despatched it by [a messenger - boy]1516-a messenger - boy , who returned presently with a word to the effect that [she]235-the countess olenska was going to [Skuytercliff]60-skuytercliff the next morning to stay over Sunday with [the van der Luydens]275-the van der luydens , but that [he]256-archer would find [her]235-the countess olenska alone that evening after dinner . The note was written on a rather untidy half - sheet , without date or address , but [her]235-the countess olenska hand was firm and free . [He]256-archer was amused at the idea of [her]235-the countess olenska week - ending in [the stately solitude of [Skuytercliff]60-skuytercliff]1517-the stately solitude of skuytercliff , but immediately afterward felt that there , of all places , [she]235-the countess olenska would most feel the chill of minds rigorously averted from the " unpleasant . "[235-the countess olenska]

[He]256-archer was at [Mr. Letterblair]353-mr. letterblair 's punctually at seven , glad of the pretext for excusing [himself]256-archer soon after dinner . [He]256-archer had formed [his]256-archer own opinion from the papers entrusted to [him]256-archer , and did not especially want to go into the matter with [[his]256-archer senior partner]1518-his senior partner . [Mr. Letterblair]353-mr. letterblair was [a widower]1519-a widower , and [they]1520-they dined alone , copiously and slowly , in [a dark shabby room]1521-a dark shabby room hung with yellowing prints of " The Death of [Chatham]357-chatham "[1522-a client] and " The Coronation of [Napoleon]358-napoleon . "[1522-a client] On the sideboard , between fluted Sheraton knife - cases , stood a decanter of [Haut Brion]359-haut brion , and another of the old Lanning port ( the gift of [a client]1522-a client ) , which [the wastrel Tom Lanning]360-the wastrel tom lanning had sold off a year or two before [his]360-the wastrel tom lanning mysterious and discreditable death in [San Francisco]82-san francisco -- an incident less publicly humiliating to [the family]532-the family than the sale of [the cellar]1524-the cellar .

After a velvety oyster soup came shad and cucumbers , then a young broiled turkey with corn fritters , followed by a canvas - back with currant jelly and a celery mayonnaise . [Mr. Letterblair]353-mr. letterblair , who lunched on a sandwich and tea , dined deliberately and deeply , and insisted on [[his]353-mr. letterblair guest]4276-his guest 's doing the same . Finally , when the closing rites had been accomplished , the cloth was removed , cigars were lit , and [Mr. Letterblair]353-mr. letterblair , leaning back in [his]353-mr. letterblair chair and pushing the port westward , said , spreading [his]353-mr. letterblair back agreeably to the coal fire behind [him]353-mr. letterblair : " [The whole family]4333-the whole family are against a divorce . And [I]353-mr. letterblair think rightly . "[353-mr. letterblair]

[Archer]215-archer instantly felt [himself]215-archer on the other side of the argument . " But why , [sir]4062-sir ? If there ever was a case-- "[215-archer]

" Well -- what 's the use ? [SHE]4335-her 'S here -- [he]360-the wastrel tom lanning 's there ; [the Atlantic]4336-the atlantic 's between [them]4337-them . [The young man]511-the young man knew this and was silent .

" [I]353-mr. letterblair understand , though , "[353-mr. letterblair] [Mr. Letterblair]353-mr. letterblair continued , " that [she]4335-her attaches no importance to the money . Therefore , as [the family]532-the family say , why not let well enough alone ? "[353-mr. letterblair]

[Archer]215-archer had gone to [the house]516-the house an hour earlier in full agreement with [Mr. Letterblair]353-mr. letterblair 's view ; but put into words by [this selfish , well - fed and supremely indifferent old man]1528-this selfish , well - fed and supremely indifferent old man it suddenly became the Pharisaic voice of a society wholly absorbed in barricading itself against the unpleasant .

" [I]1528-this selfish , well - fed and supremely indifferent old man think that 's for [her]4335-her to decide . "[1528-this selfish , well - fed and supremely indifferent old man]

" Yes ; but it might make some unpleasant talk if [he]645-her husband really defends the suit . "[1528-this selfish , well - fed and supremely indifferent old man]

" Unpleasant-- ! "[215-archer] said [Archer]215-archer explosively .

"[1530-his senior]

" [Mr. Archer]256-archer , [I]1531-his young partner do n't understand [you]256-archer . Do [you]256-archer want to marry into [a family]4341-a family with a scandalous divorce - suit hanging over it ? "[1531-his young partner]

[Mr. Letterblair]353-mr. letterblair put down [his]353-mr. letterblair glass of port and fixed on [[his]353-mr. letterblair young partner]1531-his young partner a cautious and apprehensive gaze .

[Archer]256-archer understood that [he]256-archer ran the risk of having [his]256-archer mandate withdrawn , and for some obscure reason [he]256-archer disliked the prospect .
