[Mr. Letterblair]353-mr. letterblair nodded approvingly at an excess of caution worthy of the best [New York]2-new york tradition , and [the young man]511-the young man , glancing at [his]511-the young man watch , pleaded an engagement and took leave .

XII .

Old - fashioned [New York]2-new york dined at seven , and the habit of after - dinner calls , though derided in [Archer]256-archer 's set , still generally prevailed . As [the young man]511-the young man strolled up [Fifth Avenue]18-fifth avenue from [Waverley Place]83-waverley place , [the long thoroughfare]1535-the long thoroughfare was deserted but for a group of carriages standing before [the Reggie Chiverses ']1536-the reggie chiverses ' ( where there was a dinner for [the Duke]1245-the duke ) , and the occasional figure of [an elderly gentleman in heavy overcoat and muffler]1538-an elderly gentleman in heavy overcoat and muffler ascending [a brownstone doorstep]1539-a brownstone doorstep and disappearing into [a gas - lit hall]1540-a gas - lit hall . Thus , as [Archer]256-archer crossed [Washington Square]49-washington square , [he]256-archer remarked that [old Mr. du Lac]361-old mr. du lac was calling on [[his]361-old mr. du lac cousins]1163-his cousins [the Dagonets]295-the dagonets , and turning down [the corner of [West Tenth Street]1543-west tenth street]1542-the corner of west tenth street [he]256-archer saw [Mr. Skipworth]354-mr. skipworth , of [[his]354-mr. skipworth own firm]1544-his own firm , obviously bound on a visit to [the Miss Lannings]293-the lannings . A little farther up [Fifth Avenue]18-fifth avenue , [Beaufort]251-beaufort appeared on [[his]251-beaufort doorstep]1545-his doorstep , darkly projected against a blaze of light , descended to [his]251-beaufort private brougham , and rolled away to a mysterious and probably unmentionable destination . It was not an Opera night , and [no one]601-no one was giving a party , so that [Beaufort]251-beaufort 's outing was undoubtedly of a clandestine nature . [Archer]256-archer connected it in [his]256-archer mind with [a little house beyond [Lexington Avenue]85-lexington avenue in which beribboned window curtains and flower - boxes had recently appeared , and before whose newly painted door the canary - coloured brougham of [Miss Fanny Ring]345-miss fanny ring]1547-a little house beyond lexington avenue in which beribboned window curtains and flower - boxes had recently appeared , and before whose newly painted door the canary - coloured brougham of miss fanny ring was frequently seen to wait .

Beyond [the small and slippery pyramid which composed [Mrs. Archer]215-archer 's world]1548-the small and slippery pyramid which composed mrs. archer 's world lay [the almost unmapped quarter inhabited by [artists]1550-artists]1549-the almost unmapped quarter inhabited by artists , [musicians]1551-musicians and [" people who wrote]4343-" people who wrote . "[230-medora manson] These scattered fragments of humanity had never shown any desire to be amalgamated with the social structure . In spite of odd ways [they]1552-they were said to be , for the most part , quite respectable ; but [they]1552-they preferred to keep to [themselves]1552-they . [Medora Manson]230-medora manson , in [her]230-medora manson prosperous days , had inaugurated a " literary salon "[1555-an intense and voluble mother] ; but it had soon died out owing to the reluctance of the literary to frequent [it]1553-it .

[Others]1554-others had made the same attempt , and there was a household of [Blenkers]362-the blenkers -- [an intense and voluble mother]1555-an intense and voluble mother , and [three blowsy daughters who imitated [her]230-medora manson]1556-three blowsy daughters who imitated her -- where [one]503-one met [Edwin Booth]363-edwin booth and [Patti]312-patti and [William Winter]364-william winter , and [the new Shakespearian actor]1558-the new shakespearian actor [George Rignold]365-george rignold , and some of [the magazine editors]1559-the magazine editors and [musical and literary critics]1560-musical and literary critics .

[Mrs. Archer]215-archer and [[her]215-archer group]1561-her group felt a certain timidity concerning [these persons]1562-these persons . [They]1562-these persons were odd , [they]1562-these persons were uncertain , [they]1562-these persons had things [one]503-one did n't know about in the background of [their]1562-these persons lives and minds . Literature and art were deeply respected in the Archer set , and [Mrs. Archer]215-archer was always at pains to tell [[her]215-archer children]707-her children how much more agreeable and cultivated society had been when it included such figures as [Washington Irving]366-washington irving , [Fitz - Greene Halleck]367-fitz - greene halleck and [the poet of " [The Culprit Fay]368-the culprit fay]4344-the poet of " the culprit fay . "[1565-the most celebrated authors of that generation] [The most celebrated authors of that generation]1565-the most celebrated authors of that generation had been " [gentlemen "]4345-gentlemen "[1565-the most celebrated authors of that generation] ; perhaps [the unknown persons who succeeded [them]1565-the most celebrated authors of that generation]1566-the unknown persons who succeeded them had gentlemanly sentiments , but [their]1565-the most celebrated authors of that generation origin , [their]1565-the most celebrated authors of that generation appearance , [their]1565-the most celebrated authors of that generation hair , [their]1565-the most celebrated authors of that generation intimacy with the stage and the Opera , made any old [New York]2-new york criterion inapplicable to [them]1565-the most celebrated authors of that generation .

" When [I]215-archer was [a girl]4346-a girl , "[215-archer] [Mrs. Archer]215-archer used to say , " [we]4347-we knew [everybody]586-everybody between [the Battery]4349-the battery and [Canal Street]86-canal street ; and only [the people one]4350-the people one knew had [carriages]4351-carriages . It was perfectly easy to place [any one]1132-any one then ; now one ca n't tell , and [I]215-archer prefer not to try . "[215-archer]

Only [old Catherine Mingott]356-old catherine mingott , with [her]356-old catherine mingott absence of moral prejudices and almost parvenu indifference to the subtler distinctions , might have bridged the abyss ; but [she]356-old catherine mingott had never opened a book or looked at a picture , and cared for music only because it reminded [her]356-old catherine mingott of gala nights at [the Italiens]87-the italiens , in the days of [her]356-old catherine mingott triumph at [the Tuileries]1567-the tuileries . Possibly [Beaufort]251-beaufort , who was [her]356-old catherine mingott match in daring , would have succeeded in bringing about a fusion ; but [[his]251-beaufort grand house]1568-his grand house and [silk - stockinged footmen]1569-silk - stockinged footmen were an obstacle to informal sociability . Moreover , [he]251-beaufort was as illiterate as [old Mrs. Mingott]217-mrs. manson mingott , and considered " [fellows who wrote "]4353-fellows who wrote "[251-beaufort] as [the mere paid purveyors of rich men]1570-the mere paid purveyors of rich men 's pleasures ; and [no one rich enough to influence [his]251-beaufort opinion]1571-no one rich enough to influence his opinion had ever questioned it .

[Newland Archer]215-archer had been aware of these things ever since [he]251-beaufort could remember , and had accepted them as part of the structure of [his]251-beaufort universe . [He]251-beaufort knew that there were societies where [painters and poets]1572-painters and poets and [novelists]1573-novelists and [men of science]1574-men of science , and even [great actors]1575-great actors , were as sought after as [Dukes]369-dukes ; [he]251-beaufort had often pictured to [himself]251-beaufort what it would have been to live in the intimacy of [drawing - rooms]1576-drawing - rooms dominated by the talk of [Merimee]370-merimee ( whose " Lettres a une Inconnue "[1577-his inseparables] was one of [[his]251-beaufort inseparables]1577-his inseparables ) , of [Thackeray]269-thackeray , [Browning]371-browning or [William Morris]372-william morris . But such things were inconceivable in [New York]2-new york , and unsettling to think of . [Archer]215-archer knew most of [the " fellows who wrote , "[1579-the musicians] [the musicians]1579-the musicians and [the painters]1580-the painters]1578-the " fellows who wrote , " the musicians and the painters : [he]251-beaufort met [them]1578-the " fellows who wrote , " the musicians and the painters at [the Century]88-the century , or at [the little musical and theatrical clubs that were beginning to come into existence]1581-the little musical and theatrical clubs that were beginning to come into existence . [He]251-beaufort enjoyed [them]1578-the " fellows who wrote , " the musicians and the painters there , and was bored with [them]1578-the " fellows who wrote , " the musicians and the painters at [the Blenkers ']1582-the blenkers ' , where [they]1578-the " fellows who wrote , " the musicians and the painters were mingled with fervid and [dowdy women who passed [them]1578-the " fellows who wrote , " the musicians and the painters about like captured curiosities]1583-dowdy women who passed them about like captured curiosities ; and even after [his]251-beaufort most exciting talks with [Ned Winsett]323-winsett [he]251-beaufort always came away with the feeling that if [[his]251-beaufort world]1584-his world was small , so was [theirs]1585-theirs , and that the only way to enlarge either was to reach a stage of manners where they would naturally merge .

[He]251-beaufort was reminded of this by trying to picture the society in which [the Countess Olenska]235-the countess olenska had lived and suffered , and also -- perhaps -- tasted mysterious joys . [He]251-beaufort remembered with what amusement [she]235-the countess olenska had told [him]251-beaufort that [[her]235-the countess olenska grandmother]834-her grandmother [Mingott]217-mrs. manson mingott and [the Wellands]321-the wellands objected to [her]235-the countess olenska living in [a " Bohemian "[235-the countess olenska] quarter]1587-a " bohemian " quarter given over to " [people who wrote]4354-people who wrote . "[235-the countess olenska] It was not the peril but the poverty that [[her]235-the countess olenska family]1193-her family disliked ; but that shade escaped [her]235-the countess olenska , and [she]235-the countess olenska supposed [they]1193-her family considered literature compromising .

[She]235-the countess olenska [herself]235-the countess olenska had no fears of it , and the books scattered about [[her]235-the countess olenska drawing - room]4289-her drawing - room ( [a part of [the house in which books were usually supposed to be " out of place "[1592-he] )]1591-the house in which books were usually supposed to be " out of place " )]1590-a part of the house in which books were usually supposed to be " out of place " ) , though chiefly works of fiction , had whetted [Archer]215-archer 's interest with such new names as those of [Paul Bourget]373-paul bourget , [Huysmans]374-huysmans , and [the Goncourt brothers]375-the goncourt brothers . Ruminating on these things as [he]1592-he approached [her]235-the countess olenska door , [he]1592-he was once more conscious of the curious way in which [she]235-the countess olenska reversed [his]1592-he values , and of the need of thinking [himself]1592-he into conditions incredibly different from any that [he]1592-he knew if [he]1592-he were to be of use in [her]235-the countess olenska present difficulty .

[Nastasia]336-nastasia opened the door , smiling mysteriously . On the bench in [the hall]736-the hall lay a sable - lined overcoat , a folded opera hat of dull silk with a gold J. B. on the lining , and a white silk muffler : there was no mistaking the fact that these costly articles were the property of [Julius Beaufort]231-beaufort .

[Archer]215-archer was angry : so angry that [he]1592-he came near scribbling a word on [his]1592-he card and going away ; then [he]1592-he remembered that in writing to [Madame Olenska]241-madame olenska [he]1592-he had been kept by excess of discretion from saying that [he]1592-he wished to see [her]241-madame olenska privately . [He]1592-he had therefore [no one]601-no one but [himself]1592-he to blame if [she]241-madame olenska had opened [her]241-madame olenska doors to [other visitors]1595-other visitors ; and [he]1592-he entered [the drawing - room]964-the drawing - room with the dogged determination to make [Beaufort]231-beaufort feel [himself]231-beaufort in the way , and to outstay [him]1592-he .

[The banker]591-the banker stood leaning against the mantelshelf , which was draped with an old embroidery held in place by brass candelabra containing church candles of yellowish wax . [He]591-the banker had thrust [his]591-the banker chest out , supporting [his]591-the banker shoulders against the mantel and resting [his]591-the banker weight on one large patent - leather foot . As [Archer]215-archer entered [he]1592-he was smiling and looking down on [[his]1592-he hostess]1243-his hostess , who sat on a sofa placed at right angles to the chimney . A table banked with flowers formed a screen behind [it]1599-it , and against the orchids and azaleas which [the young man]511-the young man recognised as tributes from [the Beaufort hot - houses]1601-the beaufort hot - houses , [Madame Olenska]241-madame olenska sat half - reclined , [her]241-madame olenska head propped on a hand and [her]241-madame olenska wide sleeve leaving the arm bare to the elbow .

It was usual for [ladies who received in the evenings]1602-ladies who received in the evenings to wear what were called " simple dinner dresses "[1602-ladies who received in the evenings] : a close - fitting armour of whale - boned silk , slightly open in the neck , with lace ruffles filling in the crack , and tight sleeves with a flounce uncovering just enough wrist to show an Etruscan gold bracelet or a velvet band . But [Madame Olenska]241-madame olenska , heedless of tradition , was attired in a long robe of red velvet bordered about the chin and down the front with glossy black fur . [Archer]215-archer remembered , on [his]1592-he last visit to [Paris]7-paris , seeing a portrait by [the new painter]1603-the new painter , [Carolus Duran]376-carolus duran , whose pictures were the sensation of [the Salon]1604-the salon , in which [the lady]663-the lady wore one of these bold sheath - like robes with [her]663-the lady chin nestling in fur . There was something perverse and provocative in the notion of fur worn in the evening in [a heated drawing - room]1606-a heated drawing - room , and in the combination of a muffled throat and bare arms ; but the effect was undeniably pleasing .

" [Lord]4355-lord love [us]4356-us -- three whole days at [Skuytercliff]60-skuytercliff ! "[231-beaufort] [Beaufort]231-beaufort was saying in [his]1607-his loud sneering voice as [Archer]215-archer entered . " [You]215-archer 'd better take all [your]215-archer furs , and a hot - water - bottle . "[231-beaufort]

" Why ? Is [the house]516-the house so cold ? "[241-madame olenska] [she]241-madame olenska asked , holding out [her]241-madame olenska left hand to [Archer]215-archer in a way mysteriously suggesting that [she]241-madame olenska expected [him]1607-his to kiss it .

" No ; but [the missus]4358-the missus is , "[231-beaufort] said [Beaufort]231-beaufort , nodding carelessly to [the young man]511-the young man .

" But [I]241-madame olenska thought [her]4358-the missus so kind . [She]4358-the missus came [herself]4358-the missus to invite [me]241-madame olenska . [Granny]244-granny says [I]241-madame olenska must certainly go . "[241-madame olenska]

" [Granny]244-granny would , of course . And [I]511-the young man say it 's a shame [you]215-archer 're going to miss the little oyster supper [I]511-the young man 'd planned for [you]215-archer at [Delmonico 's]89-delmonico 's next Sunday , with [Campanini]377-campanini and [Scalchi]378-scalchi and [a lot of jolly people]4359-a lot of jolly people . "[511-the young man]

[She]231-beaufort looked doubtfully from [the banker]591-the banker to [Archer]215-archer .

" Ah -- that does tempt [me]511-the young man ! Except the other evening at [Mrs. Struthers]260-mrs. struthers 's [I]511-the young man 've not met [a single artist]4360-a single artist since [I]511-the young man 've been [here]4019-here . "[511-the young man]

" What kind of [artists]1550-artists ? [I]215-archer know [one or two painters]4363-one or two painters , [very good fellows]4364-very good fellows , that [I]215-archer could bring to see [you]215-archer if [you]215-archer 'd allow [me]215-archer , "[215-archer] said [Archer]215-archer boldly .

" [Painters]4365-painters ? Are there [painters in [New York]2-new york]4366-painters in new york ? "[231-beaufort] asked [Beaufort]231-beaufort , in a tone implying that there could be none since [he]1610-he did not buy [their]1611-their pictures ; and [Madame Olenska]241-madame olenska said to [Archer]215-archer , with [her]241-madame olenska grave smile : " That would be charming . [XIII]379-xiii .

It was a crowded night at [[Wallack]380-wallack 's theatre]1630-wallack 's theatre .

The play was " [The Shaughraun]381-the shaughraun , "[379-xiii] with [Dion Boucicault]382-dion boucicault in the title role and [Harry Montague]383-harry montague and [Ada Dyas]384-ada dyas as [the lovers]1631-the lovers . The popularity of [the admirable English company]1632-the admirable english company was at its height , and [the Shaughraun]381-the shaughraun always packed [the house]516-the house . In [the galleries]1634-the galleries the enthusiasm was unreserved ; in [the stalls]1635-the stalls and boxes , [people]619-people smiled a little at the hackneyed sentiments and clap - trap situations , and enjoyed the play as much as [the galleries]1634-the galleries did .

There was one episode , in particular , that held [the house]516-the house from floor to ceiling . It was that in which [Harry Montague]383-harry montague , after a sad , almost monosyllabic scene of parting with [Miss Dyas]385-miss dyas , bade [her]385-miss dyas good - bye , and turned to go . [The actress]1639-the actress , who was standing near the mantelpiece and looking down into the fire , wore a gray cashmere dress without fashionable loopings or trimmings , moulded to [her]1639-the actress tall figure and flowing in long lines about [her]1639-the actress feet . Around [her]1639-the actress neck was a narrow black velvet ribbon with the ends falling down [her]1639-the actress back .

When [[her]1639-the actress wooer]1640-her wooer turned from [her]1639-the actress [she]1639-the actress rested [her]1639-the actress arms against the mantel - shelf and bowed [her]1639-the actress face in [her]1639-the actress hands . On the threshold [he]383-harry montague paused to look at [her]1639-the actress ; then [he]383-harry montague stole back , lifted one of the ends of velvet ribbon , kissed it , and left [the room]972-the room without [her]1639-the actress hearing [him]383-harry montague or changing [her]1639-the actress attitude . And on this silent parting the curtain fell .

It was always for the sake of that particular scene that [Newland Archer]215-archer went to see " [The Shaughraun]381-the shaughraun . "[383-harry montague] [He]383-harry montague thought the adieux of [Montague]383-harry montague and [Ada Dyas]384-ada dyas as fine as anything [he]383-harry montague had ever seen [Croisette]386-croisette and [Bressant]387-bressant do in [Paris]7-paris , or [Madge Robertson]388-may and [Kendal]92-kendal in [London]81-london ; in its reticence , its dumb sorrow , it moved [him]383-harry montague more than the most famous histrionic outpourings .

On the evening in question the little scene acquired an added poignancy by reminding [him]383-harry montague -- [he]383-harry montague could not have said why -- of [his]383-harry montague leave - taking from [Madame Olenska]241-madame olenska after [their]1642-their confidential talk a week or ten days earlier .

It would have been as difficult to discover any resemblance between the two situations as between the appearance of [the persons concerned]1643-the persons concerned . [Newland Archer]215-archer could not pretend to anything approaching [the young English actor]1644-the young english actor 's romantic good looks , and [Miss Dyas]385-miss dyas was [a tall red - haired woman of monumental build whose pale and pleasantly ugly face]1645-a tall red - haired woman of monumental build whose pale and pleasantly ugly face was utterly unlike [Ellen Olenska]233-ellen 's vivid countenance . Nor were [Archer]215-archer and [Madame Olenska]241-madame olenska two lovers parting in heart - broken silence ; [they]1642-their were [client]1646-client and [lawyer]1647-lawyer separating after a talk which had given [the lawyer]1648-the lawyer the worst possible impression of [the client]1649-the client 's case . Wherein , then , lay the resemblance that made [the young man]511-the young man 's heart beat with a kind of retrospective excitement ? It seemed to be in [Madame Olenska]241-madame olenska 's mysterious faculty of suggesting tragic and moving possibilities outside the daily run of experience . [She]241-madame olenska had hardly ever said a word to [him]383-harry montague to produce this impression , but it was a part of [her]241-madame olenska , either a projection of [her]241-madame olenska mysterious and outlandish background or of something inherently dramatic , passionate and unusual in [herself]241-madame olenska . [Archer]215-archer had always been inclined to think that chance and circumstance played a small part in shaping [people]619-people 's lots compared with [their]619-people innate tendency to have things happen to [them]619-people . This tendency [he]383-harry montague had felt from the first in [Madame Olenska]241-madame olenska . [The quiet , almost passive young woman]1652-the quiet , almost passive young woman struck [him]383-harry montague as exactly [the kind of person to whom things were bound to happen]1653-the kind of person to whom things were bound to happen , no matter how much [she]1652-the quiet , almost passive young woman shrank from [them]619-people and went out of [her]1652-the quiet , almost passive young woman way to avoid [them]619-people . The exciting fact was [her]1652-the quiet , almost passive young woman having lived in an atmosphere so thick with drama that [her]1652-the quiet , almost passive young woman own tendency to provoke it had apparently passed unperceived . It was precisely the odd absence of surprise in [her]1652-the quiet , almost passive young woman that gave [him]383-harry montague the sense of [her]1652-the quiet , almost passive young woman having been plucked out of a very maelstrom : the things [she]1652-the quiet , almost passive young woman took for granted gave the measure of those [she]1652-the quiet , almost passive young woman had rebelled against .

[Archer]215-archer had left [her]1652-the quiet , almost passive young woman with the conviction that [Count Olenski]278-count olenski 's accusation was not unfounded . [The mysterious person who figured in [[his]383-harry montague wife]553-his wife 's past]1654-the mysterious person who figured in his wife 's past as " [the secretary]4064-the secretary "[553-his wife] had probably not been unrewarded for [his]383-harry montague share in [her]1652-the quiet , almost passive young woman escape . The conditions from which [she]1652-the quiet , almost passive young woman had fled were intolerable , past speaking of , past believing : [she]1652-the quiet , almost passive young woman was young , [she]1652-the quiet , almost passive young woman was frightened , [she]1652-the quiet , almost passive young woman was desperate -- what more natural than that [she]1652-the quiet , almost passive young woman should be grateful to [[her]1652-the quiet , almost passive young woman rescuer]1656-her rescuer ? The pity was that [her]1652-the quiet , almost passive young woman gratitude put [her]1652-the quiet , almost passive young woman , in [the law]1657-the law 's eyes and [the world]561-the world 's , on a par with [[her]1652-the quiet , almost passive young woman abominable husband]1659-her abominable husband . [Archer]215-archer had made [her]1652-the quiet , almost passive young woman understand this , as [he]383-harry montague was bound to do ; [he]383-harry montague had also made [her]1652-the quiet , almost passive young woman understand that simplehearted kindly [New York]2-new york , on whose larger charity [she]1652-the quiet , almost passive young woman had apparently counted , was precisely [the place where [she]1652-the quiet , almost passive young woman could least hope for indulgence]1660-the place where she could least hope for indulgence .

To have to make this fact plain to [her]1652-the quiet , almost passive young woman -- and to witness [her]1652-the quiet , almost passive young woman resigned acceptance of it -- had been intolerably painful to [him]383-harry montague . [He]383-harry montague felt [himself]383-harry montague drawn to [her]1652-the quiet , almost passive young woman by obscure feelings of jealousy and pity , as if [her]1652-the quiet , almost passive young woman dumbly - confessed error had put [her]1652-the quiet , almost passive young woman at [his]383-harry montague mercy , humbling yet endearing [her]1652-the quiet , almost passive young woman . " [I]219-mrs. welland was sure [Newland]215-archer would manage it , "[219-mrs. welland] [Mrs. Welland]219-mrs. welland had said proudly of [[her]219-mrs. welland future son - in - law]679-her future son - in - law ; and [old Mrs. Mingott]217-mrs. manson mingott , who had summoned [him]383-harry montague for a confidential interview , had congratulated [him]383-harry montague on [his]383-harry montague cleverness , and added impatiently : " Silly goose ! "[217-mrs. manson mingott]

[Beaufort]231-beaufort and [Lefferts]224-lawrence lefferts made way for [him]383-harry montague , and after a few words with [Mrs. Beaufort]231-beaufort [, who always preferred to look beautiful and not have to talk]1670-, who always preferred to look beautiful and not have to talk , [Archer]215-archer seated [himself]215-archer behind [Madame Olenska]241-madame olenska . In obedience to a long - established habit , [the Wellands]321-the wellands had left the previous week for [St. Augustine]93-st. augustine , where , out of regard for the supposed susceptibility of [Mr. Welland]335-mr. welland 's bronchial tubes , [they]321-the wellands always spent the latter part of the winter . [Mr. Welland]335-mr. welland was [a mild and silent man , with no opinions but with many habits]1677-a mild and silent man , with no opinions but with many habits . With these habits none might interfere ; and one of [them]1678-them demanded that [[his]335-mr. welland wife]553-his wife and [daughter]909-daughter should always go with [him]335-mr. welland on [his]335-mr. welland annual journey to [the south]1681-the south . To preserve an unbroken domesticity was essential to [his]335-mr. welland peace of mind ; [he]335-mr. welland would not have known where [his]335-mr. welland hair - brushes were , or how to provide stamps for [his]335-mr. welland letters , if [Mrs. Welland]219-mrs. welland had not been there to tell [him]335-mr. welland .

As [all the members of [the family]532-the family]1682-all the members of the family adored [each other]558-each other , and as [Mr. Welland]335-mr. welland was the central object of [their]1682-all the members of the family idolatry , it never occurred to [[his]335-mr. welland wife]553-his wife and [May]388-may to let [him]335-mr. welland go to [St. Augustine]93-st. augustine alone ; and [[his]335-mr. welland sons , who were both in the law , and could not leave [New York]2-new york during the winter]1686-his sons , who were both in the law , and could not leave new york during the winter , always joined [him]335-mr. welland for Easter and travelled back with [him]335-mr. welland .

It was impossible for [Archer]215-archer to discuss the necessity of [May]388-may 's accompanying [[her]388-may father]1687-her father . The reputation of [[the Mingotts]227-the mingotts ' family physician]1688-the mingotts ' family physician was largely based on the attack of pneumonia which [Mr. Welland]335-mr. welland had never had ; and [his]335-mr. welland insistence on [St. Augustine]93-st. augustine was therefore inflexible . Originally , it had been intended that [May]388-may 's engagement should not be announced till [her]388-may return from [Florida]94-florida , and the fact that it had been made known sooner could not be expected to alter [Mr. Welland]335-mr. welland 's plans . [Archer]215-archer would have liked to join [the travellers]1689-the travellers and have a few weeks of sunshine and boating with [[his]335-mr. welland betrothed]596-his betrothed ; but [he]335-mr. welland too was bound by custom and conventions . Little arduous as [his]335-mr. welland professional duties were , [he]335-mr. welland would have been convicted of frivolity by [the whole Mingott clan]1691-the whole mingott clan if [he]335-mr. welland had suggested asking for a holiday in mid - winter ; and [he]335-mr. welland accepted [May]388-may 's departure with the resignation which [he]335-mr. welland perceived would have to be one of the principal constituents of married life .

" The fact is [she]4430-the dark lady in that swell box of yours 's [a neighbour of mine]4433-a neighbour of mine -- queer quarter for [such a beauty]4434-such a beauty to settle in -- and [she]4430-the dark lady in that swell box of yours 's been awfully kind to [[my]323-winsett little boy , who fell down [[her]4430-the dark lady in that swell box of yours area]4436-her area chasing [his]323-winsett kitten , and gave [himself]323-winsett a nasty cut . "[323-winsett]

A pleasant glow dilated [Archer]264-janey 's heart . " That is [the Countess Olenska]235-the countess olenska -- [a granddaughter of [old Mrs. Mingott]218-mrs. lovell mingott 's]4438-a granddaughter of old mrs. mingott 's . "[233-ellen]

[He]323-winsett slouched off across [Broadway]95-broadway , and [Archer]264-janey stood looking after [him]323-winsett and musing on [his]264-janey last words .

[Ned Winsett]323-winsett had those flashes of penetration ; they were the most interesting thing about [him]323-winsett , and always made [Archer]264-janey wonder why [they]1716-they had allowed [him]323-winsett to accept failure so stolidly at an age when [most men]1717-most men are still struggling .

[Archer]264-janey had known that [Winsett]323-winsett had [a wife]996-a wife and [child]1719-child , but [he]264-janey had never seen [them]1716-they . [The two men]1704-the two men always met at the Century , or at [some haunt of [journalists]1722-journalists and [theatrical people]1723-theatrical people , such as [the restaurant where [Winsett]323-winsett had proposed to go for a bock]1724-the restaurant where winsett had proposed to go for a bock]1721-some haunt of journalists and theatrical people , such as the restaurant where winsett had proposed to go for a bock . [He]323-winsett had given [Archer]264-janey to understand that [[his]323-winsett wife]553-his wife was [an invalid]1726-an invalid ; which might be true of [the poor lady]1727-the poor lady , or might merely mean that [she]1727-the poor lady was lacking in social gifts or in evening clothes , or in both . [Winsett]323-winsett [himself]323-winsett had a savage abhorrence of social observances : [Archer]264-janey , who dressed in the evening because [he]264-janey thought it cleaner and more comfortable to do so , and who had never stopped to consider that cleanliness and comfort are two of the costliest items in a modest budget , regarded [Winsett]323-winsett 's attitude as part of the boring " Bohemian "[323-winsett] pose that always made [fashionable people]1728-fashionable people , who changed [their]1728-fashionable people clothes without talking about it , and were not forever harping on the number of [servants one kept]1729-servants one kept , seem so much simpler and less self - conscious than the others . Nevertheless , [he]264-janey was always stimulated by [Winsett]323-winsett , and whenever [he]264-janey caught sight of [the journalist]1730-the journalist 's lean bearded face and melancholy eyes [he]264-janey would rout [him]323-winsett out of [his]264-janey corner and carry [him]323-winsett off for a long talk .

[Winsett]323-winsett was not [a journalist]1707-a journalist by choice . [He]323-winsett was [a pure man of letters , untimely born in a world that had no need of letters]1732-a pure man of letters , untimely born in a world that had no need of letters ; but after publishing one volume of brief and exquisite literary appreciations , of which one hundred and twenty copies were sold , thirty given away , and the balance eventually destroyed by [the publishers]1733-the publishers ( as per contract ) to make room for more marketable material , [he]323-winsett had abandoned [his]323-winsett real calling , and taken a sub - editorial job on [a women]1734-a women 's weekly , where fashion - plates and paper patterns alternated with [New England]42-new england love - stories and advertisements of temperance drinks .

On the subject of " Hearth - fires "[323-winsett] ( as the paper was called ) [he]323-winsett was inexhaustibly entertaining ; but beneath [his]323-winsett fun lurked the sterile bitterness of [the still young man who has tried and given up]1735-the still young man who has tried and given up . [His]323-winsett conversation always made [Archer]264-janey take the measure of [his]264-janey own life , and feel how little it contained ; but [Winsett]323-winsett 's , after all , contained still less , and though [their]1736-their common fund of intellectual interests and curiosities made [their]1736-their talks exhilarating , [their]1736-their exchange of views usually remained within the limits of a pensive dilettantism .

" The fact is , life is n't much a fit for either of [us]1736-their , "[323-winsett] [Winsett]323-winsett had once said . " [I]323-winsett 'm down and out ; nothing to be done about it . [I]323-winsett 've got only one ware to produce , and there 's no market for it here , and wo n't be in [my]323-winsett time . But [you]264-janey 're free and [you]264-janey 're well - off . Why do n't [you]264-janey get into touch ? There 's only one way to do it : to go into politics . "[323-winsett]

[Archer]264-janey threw [his]264-janey head back and laughed . There [one]503-one saw at a flash the unbridgeable difference between [men like [Winsett]323-winsett]1738-men like winsett and [the others]1739-the others -- [Archer]264-janey 's kind . [Every one in polite circles]1740-every one in polite circles knew that , in [America]28-america , " [a gentleman]4031-a gentleman could n't go into politics . "[264-janey] But , since [he]264-janey could hardly put it in that way to [Winsett]323-winsett , [he]264-janey answered evasively : " Look at the career of [the honest man in American politics]4446-the honest man in american politics ! [They]4446-the honest man in american politics do n't want [us]4447-you . "[264-janey]

" Who 's ' [they]4446-the honest man in american politics ' ? Why do n't [you]4447-you all get together and be ' [they]4446-the honest man in american politics ' [yourselves]4447-you ? "[264-janey]

[Archer]264-janey 's laugh lingered on [his]264-janey lips in a slightly condescending smile . It was useless to prolong the discussion : [everybody]586-everybody knew the melancholy fate of [the few gentlemen who had risked [their]1742-the few gentlemen who had risked their clean linen in municipal or state politics in new york clean linen in municipal or state politics in [New York]2-new york]1742-the few gentlemen who had risked their clean linen in municipal or state politics in new york . The day was past when that sort of thing was possible : [the country]1743-the country was in possession of [the bosses]1744-the bosses and [the emigrant]1745-the emigrant , and [decent people]1746-decent people had to fall back on sport or culture .

" Culture ! Yes -- if [we]4447-you had it ! But there are just a few little local patches , dying out here and there for lack of -- well , hoeing and cross - fertilising : the last remnants of the old European tradition that [[your]4447-you forebears]4448-your forebears brought with [them]4448-your forebears . But [you]4447-you 're in a pitiful little minority : [you]4447-you 've got no centre , no competition , [no audience]4449-no audience . [You]4447-you 're like the pictures on the walls of [a deserted house]4450-a deserted house : ' The Portrait of [a Gentleman]4031-a gentleman . ' [You]4447-you 'll never amount to anything , any of [you]4447-you , till [you]4447-you roll up [your]4447-you sleeves and get right down into [the muck]4452-the muck . That , or emigrate ... God ! If [I]1744-the bosses could emigrate ... "[1744-the bosses]

[Archer]264-janey mentally shrugged [his]264-janey shoulders and turned the conversation back to books , where [Winsett]323-winsett , if uncertain , was always interesting . Emigrate ! As if [a gentleman]4031-a gentleman could abandon [[his]4031-a gentleman own country]1748-his own country ! [One]503-one could no more do that than [one]503-one could roll up [one]503-one 's sleeves and go down into the muck . [A gentleman]4031-a gentleman simply stayed at [home]631-home and abstained . But [you]1754-you could n't make [a man like [Winsett]323-winsett]1755-a man like winsett see that ; and that was why [the New York of literary clubs and [exotic restaurants]1757-exotic restaurants]1756-the new york of literary clubs and exotic restaurants , though a first shake made it seem more of a kaleidoscope , turned out , in the end , to be a smaller box , with a more monotonous pattern , than the assembled atoms of [Fifth Avenue]18-fifth avenue .

The next morning [Archer]264-janey scoured [the town]1758-the town in vain for more yellow roses . In consequence of this search [he]264-janey arrived late at [the office]1759-the office , perceived that [his]264-janey doing so made no difference whatever to [any one]1132-any one , and was filled with sudden exasperation at the elaborate futility of [his]264-janey life . Why should [he]264-janey not be , at that moment , on [the sands of [St. Augustine]93-st. augustine with May Welland]1761-the sands of st. augustine with may welland ? [No one]601-no one was deceived by [his]264-janey pretense of professional activity . In [old - fashioned legal firms like that of which [Mr. Letterblair]353-mr. letterblair]1763-old - fashioned legal firms like that of which mr. letterblair was the head , and which were mainly engaged in the management of [large estates]1764-large estates and [" conservative "[1765-two or three young men] investments]4453-" conservative " investments , there were always [two or three young men]1765-two or three young men , fairly well - off , and without professional ambition , who , for a certain number of hours of each day , sat at [their]1765-two or three young men desks accomplishing trivial tasks , or simply reading the newspapers . Though it was supposed to be proper for [them]1765-two or three young men to have an occupation , the crude fact of money - making was still regarded as derogatory , and the law , being a profession , was accounted a more gentlemanly pursuit than business . But [none of [these young men]1767-these young men]1766-none of these young men had much hope of really advancing in [his]264-janey profession , or any earnest desire to do so ; and over many of [them]1767-these young men the green mould of the perfunctory was already perceptibly spreading .

It made [Archer]264-janey shiver to think that it might be spreading over [him]264-janey too . [He]264-janey had , to be sure , other tastes and interests ; [he]264-janey spent [his]264-janey vacations in European travel , cultivated [the " clever people "[1768-the " clever people " may] [May]1769-may]1768-the " clever people " may spoke of , and generally tried to " keep up , "[264-janey] as [he]264-janey had somewhat wistfully put it to [Madame Olenska]241-madame olenska . But once [he]264-janey was married , what would become of this narrow margin of life in which [his]264-janey real experiences were lived ? [He]264-janey had seen enough of [other young men who had dreamed [his]264-janey dream , though perhaps less ardently , and who had gradually sunk into the placid and luxurious routine of [[their]1765-two or three young men elders]1771-their elders]1770-other young men who had dreamed his dream , though perhaps less ardently , and who had gradually sunk into the placid and luxurious routine of their elders .

From [the office]1759-the office [he]264-janey sent a note by messenger to [Madame Olenska]241-madame olenska , asking if [he]264-janey might call that afternoon , and begging [her]241-madame olenska to let [him]264-janey find a reply at [[his]264-janey club]754-his club ; but at [the club]1418-the club [he]264-janey found nothing , nor did [he]264-janey receive any letter the following day . This unexpected silence mortified [him]264-janey beyond reason , and though the next morning [he]264-janey saw a glorious cluster of yellow roses behind [a florist]1775-a florist 's window - pane , [he]264-janey left it there . It was only on the third morning that [he]264-janey received a line by post from [the Countess Olenska]235-the countess olenska . To [his]264-janey surprise it was dated from [Skuytercliff]60-skuytercliff , whither [the van der Luydens]275-the van der luydens had promptly retreated after putting [the Duke]1245-the duke on board [[his]60-skuytercliff steamer]1777-his steamer .

" [I]1778-the writer ran away , "[1778-the writer] [the writer]1778-the writer began abruptly ( without the usual preliminaries ) , " the day after [I]1779-i saw [you]4454-you at the play , and [these kind friends]4455-these kind friends have taken [me]1779-i in . [I]1779-i wanted to be quiet , and think things over . [You]4454-you were right in telling [me]1779-i how kind [they]4455-these kind friends were ; [I]1779-i feel [myself]1779-i so safe here . [I]1779-i wish that [you]4454-you were with [us]4456-us . "[1779-i] [She]1779-i ended with a conventional " Yours sincerely , "[1779-i] and without any allusion to the date of [her]1779-i return .

The tone of the note surprised [the young man]511-the young man . What was [Madame Olenska]241-madame olenska running away from , and why did [she]241-madame olenska feel the need to be safe ? [His]511-the young man first thought was of some dark menace from abroad ; then [he]511-the young man reflected that [he]511-the young man did not know [her]241-madame olenska epistolary style , and that it might run to picturesque exaggeration . [Women]3970-women always exaggerated ; and moreover [she]241-madame olenska was not wholly at [her]241-madame olenska ease in English , which [she]241-madame olenska often spoke as if [she]241-madame olenska were translating from the French . " Je [me]241-madame olenska suis evadee-- "[241-madame olenska] put in that way , the opening sentence immediately suggested that [she]241-madame olenska might merely have wanted to escape from a boring round of engagements ; which was very likely true , for [he]511-the young man judged [her]241-madame olenska to be capricious , and easily wearied of the pleasure of the moment .

It amused [him]511-the young man to think of the van der [Luydens]275-the van der luydens ' having carried [her]241-madame olenska off to [Skuytercliff]60-skuytercliff on a second visit , and this time for an indefinite period . The doors of [Skuytercliff]60-skuytercliff were rarely and grudgingly opened to [visitors]1782-visitors , and a chilly week - end was the most ever offered to [the few thus privileged]1783-the few thus privileged . But [Archer]264-janey had seen , on [his]264-janey last visit to [Paris]7-paris , the delicious play of [Labiche]391-labiche , " Le Voyage de [M. [The van der Luydens]275-the van der luydens had rescued [Madame Olenska]241-madame olenska from a doom almost as icy ; and though there were many other reasons for being attracted to [her]241-madame olenska , [Archer]264-janey knew that beneath [them]1786-them all lay the gentle and obstinate determination to go on rescuing [her]241-madame olenska .

[He]264-janey felt a distinct disappointment on learning that [she]241-madame olenska was away ; and almost immediately remembered that , only the day before , [he]264-janey had refused an invitation to spend the following Sunday with [the Reggie Chiverses]285-the reggie chiverses at [[their]1787-their house on [the Hudson]61-the hudson]1788-their house on the hudson , [a few miles below [Skuytercliff]60-skuytercliff]1789-a few miles below skuytercliff .

[He]264-janey had had [his]264-janey fill long ago of the noisy friendly parties at [Highbank]96-highbank , with coasting , ice - boating , sleighing , long tramps in the snow , and a general flavour of mild flirting and milder practical jokes . [He]264-janey had just received a box of new books from [his]264-janey [London]81-london book - seller , and had preferred the prospect of a quiet Sunday at [home]631-home with [his]264-janey spoils . But [he]264-janey now went into [the club writing - room]1791-the club writing - room , wrote a hurried telegram , and told [the servant]1792-the servant to send it immediately . [He]264-janey knew that [Mrs. Reggie]393-reggie chivers did n't object to [[her]393-reggie chivers visitors]823-her visitors ' suddenly changing [their]823-her visitors minds , and that there was always a room to spare in [[her]393-reggie chivers elastic house]1794-her elastic house .

[XV .

Newland Archer]394-archer arrived at [the Chiverses ']248-the headly chiverses on Friday evening , and on Saturday went conscientiously through all the rites appertaining to a week - end at [Highbank]96-highbank .

But on Sunday after luncheon [he]264-janey borrowed [a cutter]1808-a cutter , and drove over to [Skuytercliff]60-skuytercliff .

[People]619-people had always been told that [the house at [Skuytercliff]60-skuytercliff]1810-the house at skuytercliff was [an Italian villa]1811-an italian villa . [Those who had never been to]1812-those who had never been to [Italy]65-italy believed [it]1810-the house at skuytercliff ; so did some who had . [The house]516-the house had been built by [Mr. van der Luyden]302-mr. van der luyden in [his]302-mr. van der luyden youth , on [his]302-mr. van der luyden return from the " grand tour , "[302-mr. van der luyden] and in anticipation of [his]302-mr. van der luyden approaching marriage with [Miss Louisa Dagonet]297-louisa . Against the uniform sheet of snow and the greyish winter sky [the Italian villa]1822-the italian villa loomed up rather grimly ; even in [summer]1823-summer [it]1822-the italian villa kept [its]1822-the italian villa distance , and the boldest coleus bed had never ventured nearer than thirty feet from [its]1822-the italian villa awful front . " [Mr. van der Luyden]302-mr. van der luyden , "[925-the butler] [the butler]925-the butler continued , " is in , [sir]4062-sir ; but [my]925-the butler impression is that [he]302-mr. van der luyden is either finishing [his]302-mr. van der luyden nap or else reading yesterday 's Evening Post . [A groom]1830-a groom took [the cutter]1831-the cutter to [the stables]1832-the stables , and [Archer]215-archer struck through [the park]1301-the park to [the high - road]1834-the high - road . Presently , however , coming down a foot - path that crossed [the highway]1838-the highway , [he]925-the butler caught sight of [a slight figure in a red cloak]1839-a slight figure in a red cloak , with a big dog running ahead . [He]925-the butler hurried forward , and [Madame Olenska]241-madame olenska stopped short with a smile of welcome .

" Ah , [you]925-the butler 've come ! "[241-madame olenska] [she]241-madame olenska said , and drew [her]241-madame olenska hand from [her]241-madame olenska muff .

"[925-the butler]

[She]241-madame olenska shrugged [her]241-madame olenska shoulders , with a little movement like [Nastasia]336-nastasia 's , and rejoined in a lighter tone : " Shall [we]4463-we walk on ? " Oh , presently -- let 's run a race first : [my]241-madame olenska feet are freezing to the ground , "[241-madame olenska] [she]241-madame olenska cried ; and gathering up the cloak [she]241-madame olenska fled away across the snow , the dog leaping about [her]241-madame olenska with challenging barks . [She]241-madame olenska looked up at [him]925-the butler and smiled . " [I]241-madame olenska knew [you]925-the butler 'd come ! "[241-madame olenska]

" That shows [you]241-madame olenska wanted [me]925-the butler to , "[925-the butler] [he]925-the butler returned , with a disproportionate joy in [their]1840-they nonsense . " Where did [you]241-madame olenska come from ? "[241-madame olenska] [Madame Olenska]241-madame olenska asked .

[One]503-one ca n't be alone for a minute in [that great seminary of [a house]4071-a house]4470-that great seminary of a house , with all the doors wide open , and always [a servant]4472-a servant bringing tea , or a log for the fire , or the newspaper ! "[241-madame olenska]

" Ah , [you]925-the butler do n't like [us]1843-we ! "[215-archer] [Archer]215-archer exclaimed .

[They]1843-we were walking past [the house of the old Patroon]1844-the house of the old patroon , with [its]1844-the house of the old patroon squat walls and small square windows compactly grouped about a central chimney . " Why -- [the house]516-the house is open ! "[1845-his] [he]1845-his said .

[She]215-archer stood still . " No ; only for today , at least . "[215-archer] [She]215-archer ran up the steps and tried the door . " It 's still unlocked -- what luck ! Come in and [we]1843-we can have a quiet talk . "[215-archer]

[He]1845-his followed [her]215-archer into [the narrow passage]1846-the narrow passage . [His]1845-his spirits , which had dropped at [her]215-archer last words , rose with an irrational leap . [The homely little house]1847-the homely little house stood there , [its]1847-the homely little house panels and brasses shining in the firelight , as if magically created to receive them . A big bed of embers still gleamed in the kitchen chimney , under an iron pot hung from an ancient crane . Rush - bottomed arm - chairs faced each other across the tiled hearth , and rows of Delft plates stood on shelves against the walls . [Archer]215-archer stooped over and threw a log upon the embers .

[Madame Olenska]241-madame olenska , dropping [her]241-madame olenska cloak , sat down in one of the chairs . [Archer]215-archer leaned against the chimney and looked at [her]215-archer .

" [You]215-archer 're laughing now ; but when [you]215-archer wrote [me]1845-his [you]215-archer were unhappy , "[1845-his] [he]1845-his said .

" Yes . "[215-archer] [She]215-archer paused . " But [I]215-archer ca n't feel unhappy when [you]1845-his 're [here]4019-here . "[215-archer]

" [I]1845-his sha'n't be here long , "[1845-his] [he]1845-his rejoined , [his]1845-his lips stiffening with the effort to say just so much and no more .

" No ; [I]215-archer know . But [I]215-archer 'm improvident : [I]215-archer live in the moment when [I]215-archer 'm happy . "[215-archer]

The words stole through [him]1845-his like a temptation , and to close [his]1845-his senses to it [he]1845-his moved away from the hearth and stood gazing out at the black tree - boles against the snow . But it was as if [she]215-archer too had shifted [her]215-archer place , and [he]1845-his still saw [her]215-archer , between [himself]1845-his and the trees , drooping over the fire with [her]215-archer indolent smile . [Archer]215-archer 's heart was beating insubordinately . What if it were from [him]1845-his that [she]215-archer had been running away , and if [she]215-archer had waited to tell [him]1845-his so till [they]1848-they were here alone together in [this secret room]1849-this secret room ?

" [Ellen]261-ellen , if [I]1845-his 'm really a help to [you]261-ellen -- if [you]261-ellen really wanted [me]1845-his to come -- tell [me]1845-his what 's wrong , tell [me]1845-his what it is [you]261-ellen 're running away from , "[1845-his] [he]1845-his insisted .

[He]1845-his spoke without shifting [his]1845-his position , without even turning to look at [her]215-archer : if the thing was to happen , it was to happen in this way , with the whole width of [the room]972-the room between [them]1848-they , and [his]1845-his eyes still fixed on the outer snow .

For a long moment [she]215-archer was silent ; and in that moment [Archer]215-archer imagined [her]215-archer , almost heard [her]215-archer , stealing up behind [him]1845-his to throw [her]215-archer light arms about [his]1845-his neck . While [he]1845-his waited , soul and body throbbing with the miracle to come , [his]1845-his eyes mechanically received the image of [a heavily - coated man with [his]1851-a heavily - coated man with his fur collar turned up who was advancing along the path to the house fur collar turned up who was advancing along the path to [the house]516-the house]1851-a heavily - coated man with his fur collar turned up who was advancing along the path to the house . [The man]1507-the man was [Julius Beaufort]231-beaufort .

" Ah-- ! "[215-archer] [Archer]215-archer cried , bursting into a laugh .

[Madame Olenska]241-madame olenska had sprung up and moved to [his]1845-his side , slipping [her]241-madame olenska hand into [his]1845-his ; but after a glance through the window [her]241-madame olenska face paled and [she]241-madame olenska shrank back .

" So that was it ? "[215-archer] [Archer]215-archer said derisively .

" [I]241-madame olenska did n't know [he]1507-the man was [here]4019-here , "[241-madame olenska] [Madame Olenska]241-madame olenska murmured . [Her]241-madame olenska hand still clung to [Archer]215-archer 's ; but [he]1845-his drew away from [her]241-madame olenska , and walking out into [the passage]1854-the passage threw open the door of [the house]516-the house .

" Hallo , [Beaufort]231-beaufort -- this way ! [Madame Olenska]241-madame olenska was expecting [you]231-beaufort , "[1845-his] [he]1845-his said .

During [his]1845-his journey back to [New York]2-new york the next morning , [Archer]215-archer relived with a fatiguing vividness [his]1845-his last moments at [Skuytercliff]60-skuytercliff .

[Beaufort]231-beaufort , though clearly annoyed at finding [him]1845-his with [Madame Olenska]241-madame olenska , had , as usual , carried off the situation high - handedly . [His]1845-his way of ignoring [people whose presence]1856-people whose presence inconvenienced [him]1845-his actually gave [them]1856-people whose presence , if [they]1856-people whose presence were sensitive to it , a feeling of invisibility , of nonexistence . [Archer]215-archer , as [the three]1857-the three strolled back through [the park]1301-the park , was aware of this odd sense of disembodiment ; and humbling as it was to [his]1845-his vanity it gave [him]1845-his the ghostly advantage of observing unobserved .

[Beaufort]231-beaufort had entered [the little house]4164-the little house with [his]1845-his usual easy assurance ; but [he]1845-his could not smile away the vertical line between [his]1845-his eyes . It was fairly clear that [Madame Olenska]241-madame olenska had not known that [he]1845-his was coming , though [her]241-madame olenska words to [Archer]215-archer had hinted at the possibility ; at any rate , [she]241-madame olenska had evidently not told [him]1845-his where [she]241-madame olenska was going when [she]241-madame olenska left [New York]2-new york , and [her]241-madame olenska unexplained departure had exasperated [him]1845-his . The ostensible reason of [his]1845-his appearance was the discovery , the very night before , of [a " perfect little house]4483-a " perfect little house , "[1845-his] not in [the market]1860-the market , which was really just the thing for [her]241-madame olenska , but would be snapped up instantly if [she]241-madame olenska did n't take it ; and [he]1845-his was loud in mock - reproaches for the dance [she]241-madame olenska had led [him]1845-his in running away just as [he]1845-his had found it .

" If only this new dodge for talking along a wire had been a little bit nearer perfection [I]1845-his might have told [you]241-madame olenska all this from [town]1110-town , and been toasting [my]1845-his toes before the club fire at this minute , instead of tramping after [you]241-madame olenska through the snow , "[1845-his] [he]1845-his grumbled , disguising a real irritation under the pretence of it ; and at this opening [Madame Olenska]241-madame olenska twisted the talk away to the fantastic possibility that [they]1861-they might one day actually converse with [each other]558-each other from [street]1863-street to [street]1863-street , or even -- incredible dream!--from [one town]1865-one town to another . This struck from all three allusions to [Edgar Poe]396-edgar poe and [Jules Verne]397-jules verne , and such platitudes as naturally rise to the lips of the most intelligent when [they]1861-they are talking against time , and dealing with a new invention in which it would seem ingenuous to believe too soon ; and the question of the telephone carried [them]1861-they safely back to [the big house]1866-the big house .

[Mrs. van der Luyden]296-mrs. van der luyden had not yet returned ; and [Archer]215-archer took [his]1845-his leave and walked off to fetch the cutter , while [Beaufort]231-beaufort followed [the Countess Olenska]235-the countess olenska [indoors]1867-indoors . It was probable that , little as [the van der Luydens]275-the van der luydens encouraged unannounced visits , [he]1845-his could count on being asked to dine , and sent back to [the station]1868-the station to catch [the nine o'clock train]1869-the nine o'clock train ; but more than that [he]1845-his would certainly not get , for it would be inconceivable to [[his]1845-his hosts]1870-his hosts that [a gentleman travelling without luggage]1871-a gentleman travelling without luggage should wish to spend the night , and distasteful to [them]1870-his hosts to propose it to [a person with whom [they]1870-his hosts were on terms of such limited cordiality as [Beaufort]231-beaufort]1872-a person with whom they were on terms of such limited cordiality as beaufort .

[Beaufort]231-beaufort knew all this , and must have foreseen it ; and [his]1845-his taking the long journey for so small a reward gave the measure of [his]1845-his impatience . [He]1845-his was undeniably in pursuit of [the Countess Olenska]235-the countess olenska ; and [Beaufort]231-beaufort had only one object in view in [his]1845-his pursuit of [pretty women]1873-pretty women . [[His]1845-his dull and childless home]1874-his dull and childless home had long since palled on [him]1845-his ; and in addition to more permanent consolations [he]1845-his was always in quest of amorous adventures in [his]1845-his own set . This was [the man from whom [Madame Olenska]241-madame olenska]1875-the man from whom madame olenska was avowedly flying : the question was whether [she]241-madame olenska had fled because [his]1845-his importunities displeased [her]241-madame olenska , or because [she]241-madame olenska did not wholly trust [herself]241-madame olenska to resist [them]1876-them ; unless , indeed , all [her]241-madame olenska talk of flight had been a blind , and [her]241-madame olenska departure no more than a manoeuvre .

[Archer]215-archer did not really believe this . Little as [he]1877-he had actually seen of [Madame Olenska]241-madame olenska , [he]1877-he was beginning to think that [he]1877-he could read [her]241-madame olenska face , and if not [her]241-madame olenska face , [her]241-madame olenska voice ; and both had betrayed annoyance , and even dismay , at [Beaufort]231-beaufort 's sudden appearance . But , after all , if this were the case , was it not worse than if [she]241-madame olenska had left [New York]2-new york for the express purpose of meeting [him]1845-his ? If [she]241-madame olenska had done that , [she]241-madame olenska ceased to be an object of interest , [she]241-madame olenska threw in [her]241-madame olenska lot with the vulgarest of [dissemblers]1878-dissemblers : [a woman engaged in a love affair with [Beaufort]231-beaufort " classed "[241-madame olenska] [herself]241-madame olenska irretrievably]1879-a woman engaged in a love affair with beaufort " classed " herself irretrievably .

No , it was worse a thousand times if , judging [Beaufort]231-beaufort , and probably despising [him]1845-his , [she]241-madame olenska was yet drawn to [him]1845-his by all that gave [him]1845-his an advantage over [the other men about [her]241-madame olenska]1880-the other men about her : [his]1845-his habit of [two continents]1881-two continents and two societies , [his]1845-his familiar association with [artists]1550-artists and [actors]4369-actors and [people]619-people generally in [the world]561-the world 's eye , and [his]1845-his careless contempt for local prejudices . [Beaufort]231-beaufort was vulgar , [he]1845-his was uneducated , [he]1845-his was purse - proud ; but the circumstances of [his]1845-his life , and a certain native shrewdness , made [him]1845-his better worth talking to than [many men]1886-many men , morally and socially [[his]1845-his betters]1887-his betters , whose horizon was bounded by [the Battery]15-the battery and [the Central Park]1888-the central park . How should [any one coming from [a wider world]1890-a wider world]1889-any one coming from a wider world not feel the difference and be attracted by it ?

[Madame Olenska]241-madame olenska , in a burst of irritation , had said to [Archer]215-archer that [he]1845-his and [she]241-madame olenska did not talk the same language ; and [the young man]511-the young man knew that in some respects this was true . But [Beaufort]231-beaufort understood every turn of [her]241-madame olenska dialect , and spoke it fluently : [his]1845-his view of life , [his]1845-his tone , [his]1845-his attitude , were merely a coarser reflection of those revealed in [Count Olenski]278-count olenski 's letter . This might seem to be to [his]1845-his disadvantage with [[Count Olenski]278-count olenski 's wife]1622-count olenski 's wife ; but [Archer]215-archer was too intelligent to think that [a young woman like [Ellen Olenska]233-ellen]1893-a young woman like ellen olenska would necessarily recoil from everything that reminded [her]1893-a young woman like ellen olenska of [her]1893-a young woman like ellen olenska past . [She]1893-a young woman like ellen olenska might believe [herself]1893-a young woman like ellen olenska wholly in revolt against it ; but what had charmed [her]1893-a young woman like ellen olenska in it would still charm [her]1893-a young woman like ellen olenska , even though it were against [her]1893-a young woman like ellen olenska will .

Thus , with a painful impartiality , did [the young man]511-the young man make out the case for [Beaufort]231-beaufort , and for [[Beaufort]231-beaufort 's victim]1895-beaufort 's victim . A longing to enlighten [her]1895-beaufort 's victim was strong in [him]511-the young man ; and there were moments when [he]511-the young man imagined that all [she]1895-beaufort 's victim asked was to be enlightened .

That evening [he]511-the young man unpacked [his]511-the young man books from [London]81-london . The box was full of things [he]511-the young man had been waiting for impatiently ; a new volume of [Herbert Spencer]398-herbert spencer , another collection of the prolific [Alphonse Daudet]399-alphonse daudet 's brilliant tales , and a novel called " Middlemarch , "[1896-the book - lover] as to which there had lately been interesting things said in the reviews . [He]511-the young man had declined three dinner invitations in favour of this feast ; but though [he]511-the young man turned the pages with the sensuous joy of [the book - lover]1896-the book - lover , [he]511-the young man did not know what [he]511-the young man was reading , and one book after another dropped from [his]511-the young man hand . Suddenly , among [them]1897-them , [he]511-the young man lit on a small volume of verse which [he]511-the young man had ordered because the name had attracted [him]511-the young man : " [The House of Life]4485-the house of life . "[511-the young man] [He]511-the young man took it up , and found [himself]511-the young man plunged in an atmosphere unlike any [he]511-the young man had ever breathed in books ; so warm , so rich , and yet so ineffably tender , that it gave a new and haunting beauty to the most elementary of human passions . All through the night [he]511-the young man pursued through those enchanted pages the vision of [a woman who had the face of [Ellen Olenska]233-ellen]1898-a woman who had the face of ellen olenska ; but when [he]511-the young man woke the next morning , and looked out at [the brownstone houses across [the street]1900-the street]1899-the brownstone houses across the street , and thought of [his]511-the young man desk in [[Mr. Letterblair]353-mr. letterblair 's office]1494-mr. letterblair 's office , and [the family pew in [Grace Church]99-grace church]1902-the family pew in grace church , [his]511-the young man hour in [the park of [Skuytercliff]60-skuytercliff]1903-the park of skuytercliff became as far outside the pale of probability as the visions of the night .

" [Mercy]344-mercy , how pale [you]511-the young man look , [Newland]394-archer ! "[264-janey] [Janey]264-janey commented over the coffee - cups at breakfast ; and [[his]511-the young man mother]512-his mother added : " [Newland]215-archer , [dear]3991-dear , [I]264-janey 've noticed lately that [you]511-the young man 've been coughing ; [I]264-janey do hope [you]511-the young man 're not letting [yourself]511-the young man be overworked ? "[264-janey] For it was the conviction of [both ladies]1905-both ladies that , under the iron despotism of [[his]511-the young man senior partners]1906-his senior partners , [the young man]511-the young man 's life was spent in the most exhausting professional labours -- and [he]511-the young man had never thought it necessary to undeceive [them]1906-his senior partners .

The next two or three days dragged by heavily . The taste of the usual was like cinders in [his]511-the young man mouth , and there were moments when [he]511-the young man felt as if [he]511-the young man were being buried alive under [his]511-the young man future . [He]511-the young man heard nothing of [the Countess Olenska]235-the countess olenska , or of [the perfect little house]1908-the perfect little house , and though [he]511-the young man met [Beaufort]231-beaufort at [the club]1418-the club [they]1910-they merely nodded at [each other]558-each other across the whist - tables . It was not till the fourth evening that [he]511-the young man found a note awaiting [him]511-the young man on [his]511-the young man return [home]631-home . " Come late tomorrow : [I]511-the young man must explain to [you]231-beaufort . [Ellen]233-ellen . "[511-the young man] These were the only words it contained .

[The young man]511-the young man , who was dining out , thrust the note into [his]511-the young man pocket , smiling a little at the Frenchness of the " to [you]231-beaufort . "[511-the young man] After dinner [he]511-the young man went to a play ; and it was not until [his]511-the young man return [home]631-home , after midnight , that [he]511-the young man drew [Madame Olenska]241-madame olenska 's missive out again and re - read it slowly a number of times . There were several ways of answering it , and [he]511-the young man gave considerable thought to each one during the watches of an agitated night . That on which , when morning came , [he]511-the young man finally decided was to pitch some clothes into a portmanteau and jump on board [a boat]1915-a boat that was leaving that very afternoon for [St. Augustine]93-st. augustine .

XVI .

When [Archer]264-janey walked down [the sandy main street of St. Augustine]1916-the sandy main street of st. augustine to [the house which had been pointed out to [him]264-janey as [Mr. Welland]335-mr. welland 's]1917-the house which had been pointed out to him as mr. welland 's , and saw [May Welland]226-may standing under a magnolia with the sun in [her]226-may hair , [he]264-janey wondered why [he]264-janey had waited so long to come .

Here was the truth , here was reality , here was the life that belonged to [him]511-the young man ; and [he]511-the young man , who fancied [himself]511-the young man so scornful of arbitrary restraints , had been afraid to break away from [his]511-the young man desk because of what [people]619-people might think of [his]511-the young man stealing a holiday !

[Her]226-may first exclamation was : " [Newland]215-archer -- has anything happened ? "[226-may] and it occurred to [him]511-the young man that it would have been more " feminine "[226-may] if [she]226-may had instantly read in [his]511-the young man eyes why [he]511-the young man had come . But when [he]511-the young man answered : " Yes -- [I]511-the young man found [I]511-the young man had to see [you]226-may , "[511-the young man] [her]226-may happy blushes took the chill from [her]226-may surprise , and [he]511-the young man saw how easily [he]511-the young man would be forgiven , and how soon even [Mr. Letterblair]353-mr. letterblair 's mild disapproval would be smiled away by [a tolerant family]1919-a tolerant family .

Early as it was , [the main street]1920-the main street was no place for any but formal greetings , and [Archer]264-janey longed to be alone with [May]226-may , and to pour out all [his]264-janey tenderness and [his]264-janey impatience . It still lacked an hour to [the late Welland]226-may breakfast - time , and instead of asking [him]511-the young man to come in [she]226-may proposed that [they]1921-they should walk out to [an old orange - garden beyond [the town]1758-the town]1922-an old orange - garden beyond the town . [She]226-may had just been for a row on [the river]1924-the river , and the sun that netted the little waves with gold seemed to have caught [her]226-may in its meshes . Across the warm brown of [her]226-may cheek [her]226-may blown hair glittered like silver wire ; and [her]226-may eyes too looked lighter , almost pale in their youthful limpidity . As [she]226-may walked beside [Archer]264-janey with [her]226-may long swinging gait [her]226-may face wore the vacant serenity of [a young marble athlete]1925-a young marble athlete .

To [Archer]264-janey 's strained nerves the vision was as soothing as the sight of the blue sky and [the lazy river]1926-the lazy river . [They]1921-they sat down on a bench under the orange - trees and [he]511-the young man put [his]511-the young man arm about [her]226-may and kissed [her]226-may . It was like drinking at a cold spring with the sun on it ; but [his]511-the young man pressure may have been more vehement than [he]511-the young man had intended , for the blood rose to [her]226-may face and [she]226-may drew back as if [he]511-the young man had startled [her]226-may .

" What is it ? "[511-the young man] [he]511-the young man asked , smiling ; and [she]226-may looked at [him]511-the young man with surprise , and answered : " Nothing . "[226-may]

A slight embarrassment fell on [them]1921-they , and [her]226-may hand slipped out of [his]511-the young man . It was the only time that [he]511-the young man had kissed [her]226-may on the lips except for [their]1921-they fugitive embrace in [the Beaufort conservatory]1927-the beaufort conservatory , and [he]511-the young man saw that [she]226-may was disturbed , and shaken out of [her]226-may cool boyish composure .

" Tell [me]511-the young man what [you]226-may do all day , "[511-the young man] [he]511-the young man said , crossing [his]511-the young man arms under [his]511-the young man tilted - back head , and pushing [his]511-the young man hat forward to screen the sun - dazzle . To let [her]226-may talk about familiar and simple things was the easiest way of carrying on [his]511-the young man own independent train of thought ; and [he]511-the young man sat listening to [her]226-may simple chronicle of swimming , sailing and riding , varied by an occasional dance at [the primitive inn]1928-the primitive inn when [a man - of - war]1929-a man - of - war came in . [A few pleasant people from [Philadelphia]32-philadelphia and [Baltimore]52-baltimore]1930-a few pleasant people from philadelphia and baltimore were picknicking at [the inn]1931-the inn , and [the Selfridge Merrys]282-the selfridge merrys had come down for three weeks because [Kate Merry]400-kate merry had had bronchitis . [They]282-the selfridge merrys were planning to lay out [a lawn tennis court on [the sands]1933-the sands]1932-a lawn tennis court on the sands ; but [no one]601-no one but [Kate]400-kate merry and [May]226-may had racquets , and [most of [the people]1936-the people]1935-most of the people had not even heard of the game .

All this kept [her]226-may very busy , and [she]226-may had not had time to do more than look at the little vellum book that [Archer]264-janey had sent [her]226-may the week before ( the " Sonnets from [the Portuguese]4487-the portuguese "[226-may] ) ; but [she]226-may was learning by heart " How [they]1936-the people brought the Good News from [Ghent]401-ghent to [Aix]100-aix , "[226-may] because it was one of the first things [he]264-janey had ever read to [her]226-may ; and it amused [her]226-may to be able to tell [him]264-janey that [Kate Merry]400-kate merry had never even heard of [a poet called [Robert Browning]371-browning]1937-a poet called robert browning .

Presently [she]226-may started up , exclaiming that [they]1938-they would be late for breakfast ; and [they]1938-they hurried back to [the tumble - down house with [its]1939-the tumble - down house with its pointless porch and unpruned hedge of plumbago and pink geraniums where the wellands were installed for the winter pointless porch and unpruned hedge of plumbago and pink geraniums where [the Wellands]321-the wellands were installed for the winter]1939-the tumble - down house with its pointless porch and unpruned hedge of plumbago and pink geraniums where the wellands were installed for the winter . [Mr. Welland]335-mr. welland 's sensitive domesticity shrank from the discomforts of [the slovenly southern hotel]1940-the slovenly southern hotel , and at immense expense , and in face of almost insuperable difficulties , [Mrs. Welland]219-mrs. welland was obliged , year after year , to improvise [an establishment partly made up of [discontented [New York]2-new york servants]1942-discontented new york servants and partly drawn from [the local African supply]1943-the local african supply]1941-an establishment partly made up of discontented new york servants and partly drawn from the local african supply .

" [The doctors]4488-the doctors want [[my]219-mrs. welland husband]4101-my husband to feel that [he]4101-my husband is in [[his]4101-my husband own home]4490-his own home ; otherwise [he]4101-my husband would be so wretched that the climate would not do [him]4101-my husband any good , "[219-mrs. welland] [she]219-mrs. welland explained , winter after winter , to the sympathising Philadelphians and [Baltimoreans]1944-baltimoreans ; and [Mr. Welland]335-mr. welland , beaming across a breakfast table miraculously supplied with the most varied delicacies , was presently saying to [Archer]264-janey : " [You]264-janey see , [[my]335-mr. welland dear fellow]4074-my dear fellow , [we]1946-we camp -- [we]1946-we literally camp . [I]335-mr. welland tell [[my]335-mr. welland wife]3988-my wife and [May]4493-may that [I]335-mr. welland want to teach [them]1946-we how to rough it . "[335-mr. welland]

[Mr.]1945-mr. and [Mrs. Welland]219-mrs. welland had been as much surprised as [[their]1946-we daughter]1947-their daughter by [the young man]511-the young man 's sudden arrival ; but it had occurred to [him]335-mr. welland to explain that [he]335-mr. welland had felt [himself]335-mr. welland on the verge of a nasty cold , and this seemed to [Mr. Welland]335-mr. welland an all - sufficient reason for abandoning any duty .

" [You]219-mrs. welland ca n't be too careful , especially toward spring , "[335-mr. welland] [he]335-mr. welland said , heaping [his]335-mr. welland plate with straw - coloured griddle - cakes and drowning them in golden syrup . " If [I]335-mr. welland 'd only been as prudent at [your]335-mr. welland age May would have been dancing at [the Assemblies]4494-the assemblies now , instead of spending [her]4493-may winters in [a wilderness]4495-a wilderness with [an old invalid]4496-an old invalid . "[335-mr. welland]

" Oh , but [I]511-the young man love it here , [Papa]402-papa ; [you]335-mr. welland know [I]511-the young man do . If only [Newland]394-archer could stay [I]511-the young man should like it a thousand times better than [New York]2-new york . "[511-the young man]

" [Newland]394-archer must stay till [he]394-archer has quite thrown off [his]394-archer cold , "[219-mrs. welland] said [Mrs. Welland]219-mrs. welland indulgently ; and [the young man]511-the young man laughed , and said [he]511-the young man supposed there was such a thing as [one]503-one 's profession .

[He]511-the young man managed , however , after an exchange of telegrams with [the firm]1467-the firm , to make [his]511-the young man cold last a week ; and it shed an ironic light on the situation to know that [Mr. Letterblair]353-mr. letterblair 's indulgence was partly due to the satisfactory way in which [[his]511-the young man brilliant young junior partner]1952-his brilliant young junior partner had settled the troublesome matter of the [Olenski]278-count olenski divorce . " [I]511-the young man 'm afraid [Ellen]233-ellen 's ideas are not at all like [ours]4497-ours . Another of [Medora]230-medora manson 's fads -- really this time it was almost prophetic ! " But European society is not given to divorce : [Countess Olenska]235-the countess olenska thought [she]233-ellen would be conforming to American ideas in asking for [her]233-ellen freedom . "[511-the young man] It was the first time that [the young man]511-the young man had pronounced [her]534-her daughter name since [he]511-the young man had left [Skuytercliff]60-skuytercliff , and [he]511-the young man felt the colour rise to [his]511-the young man cheek .

[Mrs. Welland]219-mrs. welland smiled compassionately . " That is just like the extraordinary things that [foreigners]732-foreigners invent about [us]4500-we . [Archer]256-archer made no comment on this , and [Mrs. Welland]219-mrs. welland continued : " But [we]4500-we do most thoroughly appreciate [your]256-archer persuading [Ellen]233-ellen to give up the idea . " What [we]4508-we 've all contrived to make it , "[1959-he] [he]1959-he felt like answering .
