" It 's all very well for [you]215-archer , [Newland]215-archer ; [you]215-archer KNOW [them]2309-them . But [I]427-archer shall feel so shy among [a lot of [people]619-people [I]427-archer 've never met]4754-a lot of people i 've never met . And what shall [I]427-archer wear ? "[427-archer]

[Newland]215-archer leaned back in [his]2306-his chair and smiled at [her]553-his wife . [She]553-his wife looked handsomer and more [Diana]428-diana - like than ever . The moist English air seemed to have deepened the bloom of [her]553-his wife cheeks and softened the slight hardness of [her]553-his wife virginal features ; or else it was simply the inner glow of happiness , shining through like a light under ice .

" Wear , [dearest]4517-dearest ? [I]553-his wife thought a trunkful of things had come from [Paris]7-paris last week . "[553-his wife]

" Yes , of course . [I]553-his wife meant to say that [I]553-his wife sha n't know WHICH to wear . "[553-his wife] [She]553-his wife pouted a little . " [I]553-his wife 've never dined out in [London]81-london ; and [I]553-his wife do n't want to be ridiculous . "[553-his wife]

[He]2306-his tried to enter into [her]553-his wife perplexity . " But do n't [Englishwomen]4757-englishwomen dress just like [everybody else]4381-everybody else in the evening ? "[2306-his]

" [Newland]215-archer ! How can [you]215-archer ask such funny questions ? When [they]4757-englishwomen go to [the theatre]1666-the theatre in old ball - dresses and bare heads . "[553-his wife]

" Well , perhaps [they]4757-englishwomen wear new ball - dresses at [home]631-home ; but at any rate [Mrs. Carfry]424-mrs. carfry and [Miss Harle]425-miss harle wo n't . [They]4757-englishwomen 'll wear caps like [my]2306-his mother's -- and shawls ; very soft shawls . "[2306-his]

" Yes ; but how will [the other women]4761-the other women be dressed ? "[553-his wife]

" Not as well as [you]553-his wife , [dear]3991-dear , "[2306-his] [he]2306-his rejoined , wondering what had suddenly developed in [her]553-his wife [Janey]420-janey 's morbid interest in clothes .

[She]553-his wife pushed back [her]553-his wife chair with a sigh . " That 's dear of [you]2306-his , [Newland]215-archer ; but it does n't help [me]553-his wife much . "[553-his wife]

[He]2306-his had an inspiration . " Why not wear [your]553-his wife wedding - dress ? That ca n't be wrong , can it ? "[2306-his]

" Oh , [dearest]4517-dearest ! If [I]553-his wife only had it [here]4019-here ! But it 's gone to [Paris]7-paris to be made over for next winter , and [Worth]429-worth has n't sent it back . "[553-his wife]

" Oh , well-- "[215-archer] said [Archer]215-archer , getting up . " Look here -- the fog 's lifting . If [we]2310-the newland archers made a dash for [the National Gallery]4765-the national gallery [we]2310-the newland archers might manage to catch a glimpse of the pictures . "[215-archer]

[The Newland Archers]2310-the newland archers were on [their]2310-the newland archers way [home]631-home , after a three months ' wedding - tour which [May]2312-may , in writing to [[her]2312-may girl friends]2313-her girl friends , vaguely summarised as " blissful . "[2312-may]

[They]2310-the newland archers had not gone to [the Italian Lakes]116-the italian lakes : on reflection , [Archer]215-archer had not been able to picture [[his]2306-his wife]553-his wife in that particular setting . [Her]2312-may own inclination ( after a month with the [Paris]7-paris dressmakers ) was for mountaineering in July and swimming in August . This plan [they]2310-the newland archers punctually fulfilled , spending July at [Interlaken]117-interlaken and [Grindelwald]118-grindelwald , and August at [a little place called [Etretat]119-etretat , on [the Normandy coast]2316-the normandy coast , which [some one]669-some one had recommended as quaint and quiet]2315-a little place called etretat , on the normandy coast , which some one had recommended as quaint and quiet . Once or twice , in [the mountains]2318-the mountains , [Archer]215-archer had pointed southward and said : " There 's [Italy]65-italy "[215-archer] ; and [May]226-may , [her]226-may feet in a gentian - bed , had smiled cheerfully , and replied : " It would be lovely to go [there]713-there next winter , if only [you]215-archer did n't have to be in [New York]2-new york . "[226-may]

But in reality travelling interested [her]2312-may even less than [he]2306-his had expected . [She]2312-may regarded it ( once [her]2312-may clothes were ordered ) as merely an enlarged opportunity for walking , riding , swimming , and trying [her]2312-may hand at the fascinating new game of lawn tennis ; and when [they]2310-the newland archers finally got back to [London]81-london ( where [they]2310-the newland archers were to spend a fortnight while [he]2306-his ordered [HIS]2306-his clothes ) [she]2312-may no longer concealed the eagerness with which [she]2312-may looked forward to sailing .

In [London]81-london nothing interested [her]2312-may but [the theatres]2319-the theatres and [the shops]2320-the shops ; and [she]2312-may found [the theatres]2319-the theatres less exciting than [the Paris cafes chantants]2322-the paris cafes chantants where , under the blossoming horse - chestnuts of [the Champs Elysees]120-the champs elysees , [she]2312-may had had the novel experience of looking down from [the restaurant terrace]2323-the restaurant terrace on [an audience of " cocottes]4767-an audience of " cocottes , "[2312-may] and having [[her]2312-may husband]645-her husband interpret to [her]2312-may as much of the songs as [he]2306-his thought suitable for bridal ears .

[Archer]215-archer had reverted to all [his]2306-his old inherited ideas about marriage . It was less trouble to conform with the tradition and treat [May]226-may exactly as [all [his]2306-his friends]2325-all his friends treated [[their]2325-all his friends wives]2326-their wives than to try to put into practice the theories with which [his]2306-his untrammelled bachelorhood had dallied . There was no use in trying to emancipate [a wife who had not the dimmest notion that [she]2327-a wife who had not the dimmest notion that she was not free was not free]2327-a wife who had not the dimmest notion that she was not free ; and [he]2306-his had long since discovered that [May]226-may 's only use of the liberty [she]226-may supposed [herself]226-may to possess would be to lay it on the altar of [her]226-may wifely adoration . [Her]226-may innate dignity would always keep [her]226-may from making the gift abjectly ; and a day might even come ( as it once had ) when [she]226-may would find strength to take it altogether back if [she]226-may thought [she]226-may were doing it for [his]2306-his own good . But with a conception of marriage so uncomplicated and incurious as [hers]226-may such a crisis could be brought about only by something visibly outrageous in [his]2306-his own conduct ; and the fineness of [her]226-may feeling for [him]2306-his made that unthinkable . Whatever happened , [he]2306-his knew , [she]226-may would always be loyal , gallant and unresentful ; and that pledged [him]2306-his to the practice of the same virtues .

All this tended to draw [him]2306-his back into [his]2306-his old habits of mind . If [her]226-may simplicity had been the simplicity of pettiness [he]2306-his would have chafed and rebelled ; but since the lines of [her]226-may character , though so few , were on the same fine mould as [her]226-may face , [she]226-may became the tutelary divinity of all [his]2306-his old traditions and reverences .

Such qualities were scarcely of the kind to enliven foreign travel , though they made [her]226-may so easy and pleasant [a companion]2328-a companion ; but [he]2306-his saw at once how [they]2329-their would fall into place in [their]2329-their proper setting . [He]2306-his had no fear of being oppressed by [them]2329-their , for [his]2306-his artistic and intellectual life would go on , as it always had , outside the domestic circle ; and within it there would be nothing small and stifling -- coming back to [[his]2306-his wife]553-his wife would never be like entering [a stuffy room]2331-a stuffy room after a tramp in the open . And when [they]2329-their had [children]3979-children the vacant corners in both [their]2329-their lives would be filled .

All these things went through [his]2306-his mind during [their]2329-their long slow drive from [Mayfair]121-mayfair to [South Kensington]122-south kensington , where [Mrs. Carfry]424-mrs. carfry and [[her]424-mrs. carfry sister]2288-her sister lived . [Archer]215-archer too would have preferred to escape [[their]2329-their friends]2334-their friends ' hospitality : in conformity with the family tradition [he]2306-his had always travelled as [a sight - seer and looker - on]2335-a sight - seer and looker - on , affecting a haughty unconsciousness of the presence of [[his]2306-his fellow - beings]2336-his fellow - beings . Once only , just after [Harvard]430-harvard , [he]2306-his had spent a few gay weeks at [Florence]67-florence with [a band of [queer Europeanised Americans]2338-queer europeanised americans]2337-a band of queer europeanised americans , dancing all night with [titled ladies in [palaces]2340-palaces]2339-titled ladies in palaces , and gambling half the day with [the rakes and dandies of [the fashionable club]2342-the fashionable club]2341-the rakes and dandies of the fashionable club ; but it had all seemed to [him]2306-his , though the greatest fun in [the world]561-the world , as unreal as a carnival . [These queer cosmopolitan women]2344-these queer cosmopolitan women , deep in complicated love - affairs which [they]2344-these queer cosmopolitan women appeared to feel the need of retailing to [every one [they]2344-these queer cosmopolitan women met]2345-every one they met , and [the magnificent young officers]2346-the magnificent young officers and [elderly dyed wits who were [the subjects]2348-the subjects or the recipients of [their]2344-these queer cosmopolitan women confidences]2347-elderly dyed wits who were the subjects or the recipients of their confidences , were too different from [the people [Archer]215-archer had grown up among]2349-the people archer had grown up among , too much like [expensive and rather malodorous hot - house exotics]2350-expensive and rather malodorous hot - house exotics , to detain [his]2306-his imagination long . To introduce [[his]2306-his wife]553-his wife into such a society was out of the question ; and in the course of [his]2306-his travels [no other]2352-no other had shown any marked eagerness for [his]2306-his company .

Not long after [their]2353-their arrival in [London]81-london [he]2306-his had run across [the Duke of St. Austrey]339-st. austrey , and [the Duke]1245-the duke , instantly and cordially recognising [him]2306-his , had said : " Look [me]1245-the duke up , wo n't you?"--but[1245-the duke] [no proper - spirited American]2355-no proper - spirited american would have considered that a suggestion to be acted on , and the meeting was without a sequel . [They]2353-their had even managed to avoid [[May]226-may 's English aunt]2356-may 's english aunt , [[the banker]591-the banker 's wife , who was still in [Yorkshire]123-yorkshire]2358-the banker 's wife , who was still in yorkshire ; in fact , [they]2353-their had purposely postponed going to [London]81-london till the autumn in order that [their]2353-their arrival during the season might not appear pushing and snobbish to [these unknown relatives]2359-these unknown relatives .

" Probably there 'll be nobody at [Mrs. Carfry's]431-mrs. carfry's -- [London]81-london 's [a desert]4768-a desert at this season , and [you]226-may 've made [yourself]226-may much too beautiful , "[215-archer] [Archer]215-archer said to [May]226-may , who sat at [his]2306-his side in the hansom so spotlessly splendid in [her]226-may sky - blue cloak edged with swansdown that it seemed wicked to expose [her]226-may to the [London]81-london grime .

" [I]226-may do n't want [them]2359-these unknown relatives to think that [we]4769-we dress like [savages]4770-savages , "[226-may] [she]226-may replied , with a scorn that [Pocahontas]432-pocahontas might have resented ; and [he]2306-his was struck again by the religious reverence of [even the most unworldly American women]2360-even the most unworldly american women for the social advantages of dress .

" It 's [their]2359-these unknown relatives armour , "[2306-his] [he]2306-his thought , " [their]2359-these unknown relatives defence against the unknown , and [their]2359-these unknown relatives defiance of it . "[2306-his] And [he]2306-his understood for the first time the earnestness with which [May]226-may , who was incapable of tying a ribbon in [her]226-may hair to charm [him]2306-his , had gone through the solemn rite of selecting and ordering [her]226-may extensive wardrobe .

[He]2306-his had been right in expecting the party at [Mrs. Carfry]424-mrs. carfry 's to be a small one . Besides [[their]2361-their hostess]2362-their hostess and [[her]226-may sister]2288-her sister , [they]2361-their found , in [the long chilly drawing - room]2364-the long chilly drawing - room , only [another shawled lady]2365-another shawled lady , [a genial Vicar who was [[her]226-may husband]645-her husband]2366-a genial vicar who was her husband , [a silent lad whom [Mrs. Carfry]424-mrs. carfry named as [[her]226-may nephew]2369-her nephew]2368-a silent lad whom mrs. carfry named as her nephew , and [a small dark gentleman with lively eyes whom [she]226-may introduced as [[his]2306-his tutor]2371-his tutor , pronouncing a French name as [she]226-may did so]2370-a small dark gentleman with lively eyes whom she introduced as his tutor , pronouncing a french name as she did so .

Into [this dimly - lit and dim - featured group [May Archer]215-archer]2372-this dimly - lit and dim - featured group may archer floated like a swan with the sunset on [her]215-archer : [she]215-archer seemed larger , fairer , more voluminously rustling than [[her]215-archer husband]645-her husband had ever seen [her]215-archer ; and [he]645-her husband perceived that the rosiness and rustlingness were the tokens of an extreme and infantile shyness .

" What on earth will [they]2374-their expect [me]215-archer to talk about ? "[215-archer] [her]215-archer helpless eyes implored [him]645-her husband , at the very moment that [her]215-archer dazzling apparition was calling forth the same anxiety in [their]2374-their own bosoms . But beauty , even when distrustful of itself , awakens confidence in the manly heart ; and [the Vicar]2375-the vicar and [the French - named tutor]2376-the french - named tutor were soon manifesting to [May]2377-may [their]2374-their desire to put [her]2377-may at [her]2377-may ease .

In spite of [their]2374-their best efforts , however , the dinner was a languishing affair . [Archer]215-archer noticed that [[his]645-her husband wife]553-his wife 's way of showing [herself]553-his wife at [her]553-his wife ease with [foreigners]732-foreigners was to become more uncompromisingly local in [her]553-his wife references , so that , though [her]553-his wife loveliness was an encouragement to admiration , [her]553-his wife conversation was a chill to repartee . [The Vicar]2375-the vicar soon abandoned the struggle ; but [the tutor]2381-the tutor , who spoke the most fluent and accomplished English , gallantly continued to pour it out to [her]553-his wife until [the ladies]735-the ladies , to the manifest relief of [all concerned]2383-all concerned , went up to [the drawing - room]964-the drawing - room .

[The Vicar]2375-the vicar , after a glass of port , was obliged to hurry away to a meeting , and [the shy nephew , who appeared to be an invalid]2386-the shy nephew , who appeared to be an invalid , was packed off to bed . But [Archer]215-archer and [the tutor]2381-the tutor continued to sit over [their]2374-their wine , and suddenly [Archer]215-archer found [himself]215-archer talking as [he]2381-the tutor had not done since [his]2381-the tutor last symposium with [Ned Winsett]323-winsett . [The Carfry nephew]2388-the carfry nephew , it turned out , had been threatened with consumption , and had had to leave [Harrow]124-harrow for [Switzerland]125-switzerland , where [he]2388-the carfry nephew had spent two years in [the milder air of [Lake Leman]126-lake leman]2389-the milder air of lake leman . Being [a bookish youth]2390-a bookish youth , [he]2388-the carfry nephew had been entrusted to [M. Riviere]433-m. riviere , who had brought [him]2388-the carfry nephew back to [England]31-england , and was to remain with [him]2388-the carfry nephew till [he]2388-the carfry nephew went up to [Oxford]127-oxford the following spring ; and [M. Riviere]433-m. riviere added with simplicity that [he]2388-the carfry nephew should then have to look out for another job .

It seemed impossible , [Archer]215-archer thought , that [he]2388-the carfry nephew should be long without one , so varied were [his]2388-the carfry nephew interests and so many [his]2388-the carfry nephew gifts . [He]2388-the carfry nephew was [a man of about thirty , with a thin ugly face]2391-a man of about thirty , with a thin ugly face ( May would certainly have called [him]2388-the carfry nephew common - looking ) to which the play of [his]2388-the carfry nephew ideas gave an intense expressiveness ; but there was nothing frivolous or cheap in [his]2388-the carfry nephew animation .

[[His]2388-the carfry nephew father]2392-his father , who had died young , had filled a small diplomatic post , and it had been intended that [the son]2393-the son should follow the same career ; but an insatiable taste for letters had thrown [the young man]511-the young man into journalism , then into authorship ( apparently unsuccessful ) , and at length -- after other experiments and vicissitudes which [he]2388-the carfry nephew spared [[his]2388-the carfry nephew listener]2395-his listener -- into tutoring [English youths in [Switzerland]125-switzerland]2396-english youths in switzerland . Before that , however , [he]2388-the carfry nephew had lived much in [Paris]7-paris , frequented [the Goncourt grenier]375-the goncourt brothers , been advised by [Maupassant]434-maupassant not to attempt to write ( even that seemed to [Archer]215-archer a dazzling honour ! ) , and had often talked with [Merimee]370-merimee in [[[his]2388-the carfry nephew mother]512-his mother 's house]2398-his mother 's house . [He]2388-the carfry nephew had obviously always been desperately poor and anxious ( having [a mother]2399-a mother and [an unmarried sister]2400-an unmarried sister to provide for ) , and it was apparent that [his]2388-the carfry nephew literary ambitions had failed . [His]2388-the carfry nephew situation , in fact , seemed , materially speaking , no more brilliant than [Ned Winsett]323-winsett 's ; but [he]2388-the carfry nephew had lived in a world in which , as [he]2388-the carfry nephew said , [no one who loved ideas need hunger mentally]2401-no one who loved ideas need hunger mentally . As it was precisely of that love that poor [Winsett]323-winsett was starving to death , [Archer]215-archer looked with a sort of vicarious envy at [this eager impecunious young man who had fared so richly in [his]2388-the carfry nephew poverty]2402-this eager impecunious young man who had fared so richly in his poverty .

" [You]215-archer see , [Monsieur]4771-monsieur , it 's worth everything , is n't it , to keep [one]503-one 's intellectual liberty , not to enslave [one]503-one 's powers of appreciation , [one]503-one 's critical independence ? It was because of that that [I]2402-this eager impecunious young man who had fared so richly in his poverty abandoned journalism , and took to so much duller work : tutoring and private secretaryship . There is a good deal of drudgery , of course ; but [one]503-one preserves [one]503-one 's moral freedom , what [we]4777-we call in French one 's quant a soi . And when [one]503-one hears good talk [one]503-one can join in it without compromising any opinions but [one]503-one 's own ; or [one]503-one can listen , and answer it inwardly . Ah , good conversation -- there 's nothing like it , is there ? The air of ideas is the only air worth breathing . And so [I]2402-this eager impecunious young man who had fared so richly in his poverty have never regretted giving up either diplomacy or journalism -- [two different forms of the same self - abdication]4781-two different forms of the same self - abdication . "[2402-this eager impecunious young man who had fared so richly in his poverty] [He]2402-this eager impecunious young man who had fared so richly in his poverty fixed [his]2402-this eager impecunious young man who had fared so richly in his poverty vivid eyes on [Archer]215-archer as [he]2402-this eager impecunious young man who had fared so richly in his poverty lit another cigarette . " Voyez - vous , [Monsieur]4782-monsieur , to be able to look life in the face : that 's worth living in [a garret]4783-a garret for , is n't it ? But , after all , [one]503-one must earn enough to pay for the garret ; and [I]2402-this eager impecunious young man who had fared so richly in his poverty confess that to grow old as [a private tutor]4785-a private tutor -- or a ' private ' anything -- is almost as chilling to the imagination as a second secretaryship at [Bucharest]128-bucharest . Sometimes [I]2402-this eager impecunious young man who had fared so richly in his poverty feel [I]2402-this eager impecunious young man who had fared so richly in his poverty must make a plunge : an immense plunge . "[2402-this eager impecunious young man who had fared so richly in his poverty]

[Archer]215-archer looked at [him]2402-this eager impecunious young man who had fared so richly in his poverty with startled eyes . [New York]2-new york , for [a young man who had frequented the Goncourts and [Flaubert]435-flaubert]2403-a young man who had frequented the goncourts and flaubert , and who thought the life of ideas the only one worth living ! " [New York]2-new york -- [New York]2-new york -- but must it be especially [New York]2-new york ? A sudden flush rose under [M. Riviere]433-m. riviere 's sallow skin . " [I]2402-this eager impecunious young man who had fared so richly in his poverty -- [I]2402-this eager impecunious young man who had fared so richly in his poverty thought it [[your]2402-this eager impecunious young man who had fared so richly in his poverty metropolis]4786-your metropolis : is not the intellectual life more active [there]713-there ? "[2402-this eager impecunious young man who had fared so richly in his poverty]

During the homeward drive [Archer]215-archer pondered deeply on this episode . [His]2402-this eager impecunious young man who had fared so richly in his poverty hour with [M. Riviere]433-m. riviere had put new air into [his]2402-this eager impecunious young man who had fared so richly in his poverty lungs , and [his]2402-this eager impecunious young man who had fared so richly in his poverty first impulse had been to invite [him]2402-this eager impecunious young man who had fared so richly in his poverty to dine the next day ; but [he]2402-this eager impecunious young man who had fared so richly in his poverty was beginning to understand why [married men]2408-married men did not always immediately yield to [their]2408-married men first impulses .

" [That young tutor]4792-that young tutor is [an interesting fellow]4793-an interesting fellow : [we]4794-we had some awfully good talk after dinner about books and things , "[2402-this eager impecunious young man who had fared so richly in his poverty] [he]2402-this eager impecunious young man who had fared so richly in his poverty threw out tentatively in the hansom .

[May]2409-may roused [herself]2409-may from one of the dreamy silences into which [he]2402-this eager impecunious young man who had fared so richly in his poverty had read so many meanings before six months of marriage had given [him]2402-this eager impecunious young man who had fared so richly in his poverty the key to them .

" [The little Frenchman]4795-the little frenchman ? Was n't [he]4795-the little frenchman dreadfully common ? "[2409-may] [she]2409-may questioned coldly ; and [he]2402-this eager impecunious young man who had fared so richly in his poverty guessed that [she]2409-may nursed a secret disappointment at having been invited out in [London]81-london to meet [a clergyman]2410-a clergyman and [a French tutor]2411-a french tutor . The disappointment was not occasioned by the sentiment ordinarily defined as snobbishness , but by old [New York]2-new york 's sense of what was due to it when it risked its dignity in [foreign lands]2412-foreign lands . If [[May]226-may 's parents]2413-may 's parents had entertained [the Carfrys]436-the carfrys in [Fifth Avenue]18-fifth avenue [they]2413-may 's parents would have offered [them]436-the carfrys something more substantial than [a parson]2414-a parson and [a schoolmaster]2415-a schoolmaster .

But [Archer]215-archer was on edge , and took [her]2409-may up .

" Common -- common WHERE ? "[2402-this eager impecunious young man who had fared so richly in his poverty] [he]2402-this eager impecunious young man who had fared so richly in his poverty queried ; and [she]2409-may returned with unusual readiness : " Why , [I]2409-may should say anywhere but in [[his]2402-this eager impecunious young man who had fared so richly in his poverty school - room]4796-his school - room . [Those people]4797-those people are always awkward in society . But then , "[2409-may] [she]2409-may added disarmingly , " [I]2409-may suppose [I]2409-may should n't have known if [he]2402-this eager impecunious young man who had fared so richly in his poverty was clever . "[2409-may]

[Archer]215-archer disliked [her]2409-may use of the word " clever "[2409-may] almost as much as [her]2409-may use of the word " common "[2409-may] ; but [he]2402-this eager impecunious young man who had fared so richly in his poverty was beginning to fear [his]2402-this eager impecunious young man who had fared so richly in his poverty tendency to dwell on the things [he]2402-this eager impecunious young man who had fared so richly in his poverty disliked in [her]2409-may . " Ah -- then [I]2402-this eager impecunious young man who had fared so richly in his poverty wo n't ask [him]2402-this eager impecunious young man who had fared so richly in his poverty to dine ! "[2420-may]

" Well , not on the same day with [the Carfrys]436-the carfrys , if [you]2420-may prefer [I]2420-may should n't . [Her]2420-may surprise increased with [her]2420-may indifference : [he]2402-this eager impecunious young man who had fared so richly in his poverty almost fancied that [she]2420-may suspected [him]2402-this eager impecunious young man who had fared so richly in his poverty of being tainted with " foreignness . "[2420-may]

" Chiefly to enjoy good conversation , [I]645-her husband understand , "[645-her husband] [[her]2420-may husband]645-her husband retorted perversely ; and [she]2420-may broke into an appreciative laugh . " Oh , [Newland]215-archer , how funny ! Is n't that FRENCH ? "[2420-may]

Riviere]433-m. riviere . Another after - dinner talk would have made it difficult to avoid the question of [New York]2-new york ; and the more [Archer]215-archer considered it the less [he]2402-this eager impecunious young man who had fared so richly in his poverty was able to fit [M. Riviere]433-m. riviere into any conceivable picture of [New York]2-new york as [he]2402-this eager impecunious young man who had fared so richly in his poverty knew it .

[He]2402-this eager impecunious young man who had fared so richly in his poverty perceived with a flash of chilling insight that in future many problems would be thus negatively solved for [him]2402-this eager impecunious young man who had fared so richly in his poverty ; but as [he]2402-this eager impecunious young man who had fared so richly in his poverty paid the hansom and followed [[his]2402-this eager impecunious young man who had fared so richly in his poverty wife]553-his wife 's long train into [the house]516-the house [he]2402-this eager impecunious young man who had fared so richly in his poverty took refuge in the comforting platitude that the first six months were always the most difficult in marriage . " After that [I]2402-this eager impecunious young man who had fared so richly in his poverty suppose [we]4802-we shall have pretty nearly finished rubbing off [each other]558-each other 's angles , "[2402-this eager impecunious young man who had fared so richly in his poverty] [he]2402-this eager impecunious young man who had fared so richly in his poverty reflected ; but the worst of it was that [May]226-may 's pressure was already bearing on the very angles whose sharpness [he]2402-this eager impecunious young man who had fared so richly in his poverty most wanted to keep .

XXI .

[The small bright lawn]2424-the small bright lawn stretched away smoothly to [the big bright sea]2425-the big bright sea .

The turf was hemmed with an edge of scarlet geranium and coleus , and cast - iron vases painted in chocolate colour , standing at intervals along the winding path that led to [the sea]2426-the sea , looped their garlands of petunia and ivy geranium above the neatly raked gravel .

Half way between the edge of [the cliff]2427-the cliff and [the square wooden house]2428-the square wooden house ( which was also chocolate - coloured , but with the tin roof of [the verandah]4533-the verandah striped in yellow and brown to represent an awning ) two large targets had been placed against a background of shrubbery . On the other side of [the lawn]2430-the lawn , facing the targets , was pitched [a real tent , with benches and garden - seats about [it]2431-a real tent , with benches and garden - seats about it]2431-a real tent , with benches and garden - seats about it . A number of [ladies in summer dresses]2432-ladies in summer dresses and [gentlemen in grey frock - coats and tall hats]2433-gentlemen in grey frock - coats and tall hats stood on [the lawn]2430-the lawn or sat upon the benches ; and every now and then [a slender girl in starched muslin]2435-a slender girl in starched muslin would step from [the tent]2436-the tent , bow in hand , and speed [her]2435-a slender girl in starched muslin shaft at one of the targets , while [the spectators]2148-the spectators interrupted [their]2148-the spectators talk to watch the result .

[Newland Archer]215-archer , standing on [the verandah of [the house]516-the house]2438-the verandah of the house , looked curiously down upon this scene . On each side of the shiny painted steps was a large blue china flower - pot on a bright yellow china stand . A spiky green plant filled each pot , and below [the verandah]4533-the verandah ran a wide border of blue hydrangeas edged with more red geraniums . Behind [him]2441-he , the French windows of [the drawing - rooms through which [he]2441-he had passed]2442-the drawing - rooms through which he had passed gave glimpses , between swaying lace curtains , of glassy parquet floors islanded with chintz poufs , dwarf armchairs , and velvet tables covered with trifles in silver .

[The Newport Archery Club]2443-the newport archery club always held [its]2443-the newport archery club August meeting at [the Beauforts ']2444-the beauforts ' . The sport , which had hitherto known [no rival but croquet]2445-no rival but croquet , was beginning to be discarded in favour of lawn - tennis ; but the latter game was still considered too rough and inelegant for social occasions , and as an opportunity to show off pretty dresses and graceful attitudes the bow and arrow held [their]2446-their own .

[Archer]215-archer looked down with wonder at the familiar spectacle . It surprised [him]2441-he that life should be going on in the old way when [his]2441-he own reactions to it had so completely changed . It was [Newport]105-newport that had first brought home to [him]2441-he the extent of the change . In [New York]2-new york , during the previous winter , after [he]2441-he and [May]226-may had settled down in [the new greenish - yellow house]2447-the new greenish - yellow house with the bow - window and [the Pompeian vestibule]2448-the pompeian vestibule , [he]2441-he had dropped back with relief into the old routine of [the office]1759-the office , and the renewal of this daily activity had served as a link with [his]2441-he former self . Then there had been the pleasurable excitement of choosing a showy grey stepper for [May]226-may 's brougham ( [the Wellands]321-the wellands had given [the carriage]859-the carriage ) , and the abiding occupation and interest of arranging [[his]2441-he new library]2451-his new library , which , in spite of family doubts and disapprovals , had been carried out as [he]2441-he had dreamed , with a dark embossed paper , Eastlake book - cases and " sincere "[2452-the fashionable young men of his own set] arm - chairs and tables . At the Century [he]2441-he had found [Winsett]323-winsett again , and at the Knickerbocker [the fashionable young men of [his]2441-he own set]2452-the fashionable young men of his own set ; and what with the hours dedicated to the law and those given to dining out or entertaining [friends]4143-friends at [home]631-home , with an occasional evening at the Opera or the play , the life [he]2441-he was living had still seemed a fairly real and inevitable sort of business .

But [Newport]105-newport represented the escape from duty into an atmosphere of unmitigated holiday - making . [Archer]215-archer had tried to persuade [May]226-may to spend the summer on [a remote island off [the coast of [Maine]130-maine]2456-the coast of maine]2455-a remote island off the coast of maine ( called , appropriately enough , [Mount Desert]131-mount desert ) , where [a few hardy Bostonians]2457-a few hardy bostonians and [Philadelphians]2458-philadelphians were camping in [" native "[2462-their son - in - law] cottages]4804-" native " cottages , and whence came reports of enchanting scenery and a wild , almost trapper - like existence amid [woods and waters]2459-woods and waters .

But [the Wellands]321-the wellands always went to [Newport]105-newport , where [they]321-the wellands owned one of [the square boxes on [the cliffs]2461-the cliffs]2460-the square boxes on the cliffs , and [[their]321-the wellands son - in - law]2462-their son - in - law could adduce no good reason why [he]2441-he and [May]226-may should not join [them]321-the wellands [there]713-there . As [Mrs. Welland]219-mrs. welland rather tartly pointed out , it was hardly worth while for [May]226-may to have worn [herself]226-may out trying on summer clothes in [Paris]7-paris if [she]226-may was not to be allowed to wear them ; and this argument was of a kind to which [Archer]215-archer had as yet found no answer .

[May]2464-may [herself]2464-may could not understand [his]2441-he obscure reluctance to fall in with so reasonable and pleasant a way of spending the summer . [She]2464-may reminded [him]2441-he that [he]2441-he had always liked [Newport]105-newport in [his]2441-he bachelor days , and as this was indisputable [he]2441-he could only profess that [he]2441-he was sure [he]2441-he was going to like it better than ever now that [they]2465-they were to be there together . But as [he]2441-he stood on [the Beaufort verandah]2466-the beaufort verandah and looked out on [the brightly peopled lawn]2467-the brightly peopled lawn it came home to [him]2441-he with a shiver that [he]2441-he was not going to like it at all .

It was not [May]226-may 's fault , [poor dear]2468-poor dear . If , now and then , during [their]2465-they travels , [they]2465-they had fallen slightly out of step , harmony had been restored by [their]2465-they return to the conditions [she]2464-may was used to . [He]2441-he had always foreseen that [she]2464-may would not disappoint [him]2441-he ; and [he]2441-he had been right . [He]2441-he had married ( as [most young men]2469-most young men did ) because [he]2441-he had met [a perfectly charming girl]2470-a perfectly charming girl at the moment when a series of rather aimless sentimental adventures were ending in premature disgust ; and [she]2470-a perfectly charming girl had represented peace , stability , comradeship , and the steadying sense of an unescapable duty .

[He]2441-he could not say that [he]2441-he had been mistaken in [his]2441-he choice , for [she]2470-a perfectly charming girl had fulfilled all that [he]2441-he had expected . It was undoubtedly gratifying to be [the husband of one of [the handsomest and most popular young married women in [New York]2-new york]2472-the handsomest and most popular young married women in new york , especially when [she]2470-a perfectly charming girl was also [one of the sweetest - tempered and most reasonable of [wives]2474-wives]2473-one of the sweetest - tempered and most reasonable of wives]2471-the husband of one of the handsomest and most popular young married women in new york , especially when she was also one of the sweetest - tempered and most reasonable of wives ; and [Archer]215-archer had never been insensible to such advantages . As for the momentary madness which had fallen upon [him]2441-he on the eve of [his]2441-he marriage , [he]2441-he had trained [himself]2441-he to regard it as the last of [his]2441-he discarded experiments . The idea that [he]2441-he could ever , in [his]2441-he senses , have dreamed of marrying [the Countess Olenska]235-the countess olenska had become almost unthinkable , and [she]2470-a perfectly charming girl remained in [his]2441-he memory simply as the most plaintive and poignant of a line of ghosts .

But all these abstractions and eliminations made of [his]2441-he mind a rather empty and echoing place , and [he]2441-he supposed that was one of the reasons why [the busy animated people on [the Beaufort lawn]2476-the beaufort lawn]2475-the busy animated people on the beaufort lawn shocked [him]2441-he as if [they]2475-the busy animated people on the beaufort lawn had been [children]3979-children playing in [a grave - yard]2478-a grave - yard .

[He]2441-he heard a murmur of skirts beside [him]2441-he , and [the Marchioness Manson]316-the marchioness manson fluttered out of [the drawing - room]964-the drawing - room window . As usual , [she]2470-a perfectly charming girl was extraordinarily festooned and bedizened , with a limp Leghorn hat anchored to [her]2470-a perfectly charming girl head by many windings of faded gauze , and a little black velvet parasol on a carved ivory handle absurdly balanced over [her]2470-a perfectly charming girl much larger hatbrim .

" [[My]2470-a perfectly charming girl dear]4004-my dear [Newland]215-archer , [I]2470-a perfectly charming girl had no idea that [you]215-archer and [May]226-may had arrived ! " But marriage is one long sacrifice , as [I]2470-a perfectly charming girl used often to remind [[my]2470-a perfectly charming girl Ellen--]4808-my ellen-- "[2470-a perfectly charming girl]

[Archer]215-archer 's heart stopped with the queer jerk which it had given once before , and which seemed suddenly to slam a door between [himself]2480-he and [the outer world]2481-the outer world ; but this break of continuity must have been of the briefest , for [he]2480-he presently heard [Medora]230-medora manson answering a question [he]2480-he had apparently found voice to put .

" No , [I]230-medora manson am not staying [here]4019-here , but with [the Blenkers]362-the blenkers , in [their]4810-their delicious solitude at [Portsmouth]132-portsmouth . "[230-medora manson] [She]230-medora manson drooped slightly beneath [her]230-medora manson protecting brim , and added with a faint blush : " This week [Dr. Agathon Carver]410-dr. carver is holding a series of Inner Thought meetings [there]713-there . But shall [we]4822-we go down and watch this absorbing match ? [I]230-medora manson hear [[your]4819-you May]4823-your may is one of [the competitors]4824-the competitors . "[230-medora manson]

Strolling toward [them]2482-them from [the tent]2436-the tent [Beaufort]231-beaufort advanced over [the lawn]2430-the lawn , tall , heavy , too tightly buttoned into a [London]81-london frock - coat , with one of [his]2485-his own orchids in its buttonhole . [Archer]215-archer , who had not seen [him]2485-his for two or three months , was struck by the change in [his]2485-his appearance . In the hot summer light [his]2485-his floridness seemed heavy and bloated , and but for [his]2485-his erect square - shouldered walk [he]2485-his would have looked like [an over - fed and over - dressed old man]2486-an over - fed and over - dressed old man .

There were all sorts of rumours afloat about [Beaufort]231-beaufort . In the spring [he]2485-his had gone off on a long cruise to [the West Indies]133-the west indies in [[his]2485-his new steam - yacht]2487-his new steam - yacht , and it was reported that , at various points where [he]2485-his had touched , [a lady resembling [Miss Fanny Ring]345-miss fanny ring]2488-a lady resembling miss fanny ring had been seen in [[his]2485-his company]2489-his company . [The steam - yacht]2490-the steam - yacht , built in [the Clyde]134-the clyde , and fitted with [tiled bath - rooms]2491-tiled bath - rooms and other unheard - of luxuries , was said to have cost [him]2485-his half a million ; and the pearl necklace which [he]2485-his had presented to [[his]2485-his wife]553-his wife on [his]2485-his return was as magnificent as such expiatory offerings are apt to be . [Beaufort]231-beaufort 's fortune was substantial enough to stand the strain ; and yet the disquieting rumours persisted , not only in [Fifth Avenue]18-fifth avenue but in [Wall Street]135-wall street . [Some people]694-some people said [he]2485-his had speculated unfortunately in railways , others that [he]2485-his was being bled by [one of [the most insatiable members of [her]2494-one of the most insatiable members of her profession profession]2495-the most insatiable members of her profession]2494-one of the most insatiable members of her profession ; and to every report of threatened insolvency [Beaufort]231-beaufort replied by a fresh extravagance : the building of [a new row of orchid - houses]2496-a new row of orchid - houses , the purchase of a new string of [race - horses]2497-race - horses , or the addition of a new Meissonnier or Cabanel to [[his]2485-his picture - gallery]2498-his picture - gallery .

[He]2485-his advanced toward [the Marchioness]316-the marchioness manson and [Newland]215-archer with [his]2485-his usual half - sneering smile . " [Hullo]438-hullo , [Medora]230-medora manson ! "[2485-his] [He]2485-his shook hands with [Archer]215-archer , and then , turning back with [them]2499-them , placed [himself]2485-his on [Mrs. Manson]217-mrs. manson mingott 's other side , and said , in a low voice , a few words which [[their]2499-them companion]2500-their companion did not catch .

"[2485-his]

" Ah , then it remains in [the family]532-the family , "[230-medora manson] [Medora]230-medora manson rippled ; and at that moment [they]2499-them reached [the tent]2436-the tent and [Mrs. Beaufort]231-beaufort met [them]2499-them in a girlish cloud of mauve muslin and floating veils .

[May Welland]226-may was just coming out of [the tent]2436-the tent . In [her]226-may white dress , with a pale green ribbon about the waist and a wreath of ivy on [her]226-may hat , [she]226-may had the same Diana - like aloofness as when [she]226-may had entered [the Beaufort ball - room]2503-the beaufort ball - room on the night of [her]226-may engagement . In the interval not a thought seemed to have passed behind [her]226-may eyes or a feeling through [her]226-may heart ; and though [[her]226-may husband]645-her husband knew that [she]226-may had the capacity for both [he]645-her husband marvelled afresh at the way in which experience dropped away from [her]226-may .

[She]226-may had [her]226-may bow and arrow in [her]226-may hand , and placing [herself]226-may on the chalk - mark traced on the turf [she]226-may lifted the bow to [her]226-may shoulder and took aim . The attitude was so full of a classic grace that a murmur of appreciation followed [her]226-may appearance , and [Archer]215-archer felt the glow of proprietorship that so often cheated [him]645-her husband into momentary well - being . [[Her]226-may rivals]2505-her rivals -- [Mrs. Reggie Chivers]393-reggie chivers , [the Merry girls]2506-the merry girls , and [divers rosy Thorleys]228-the thorleys , [Dagonets]295-the dagonets and [Mingotts]227-the mingotts , stood behind [her]226-may in a lovely anxious group , brown heads and golden bent above the scores , and pale muslins and flower - wreathed hats mingled in a tender rainbow . [All]2507-all were young and pretty , and bathed in summer bloom ; but [not one]2508-not one had the nymph - like ease of [[his]645-her husband wife]553-his wife , when , with tense muscles and happy frown , [she]226-may bent [her]226-may soul upon some feat of strength .

" [Gad]439-gad , "[224-lawrence lefferts] [Archer]215-archer heard [Lawrence Lefferts]224-lawrence lefferts say , " [not one of [the lot]4829-the lot]4828-not one of the lot holds the bow as [she]226-may does "[224-lawrence lefferts] ; and [Beaufort]231-beaufort retorted : " Yes ; but that 's the only kind of target [she]226-may 'll ever hit . "[231-beaufort]

[Archer]215-archer felt irrationally angry . [[His]645-her husband host]1278-his host 's contemptuous tribute to [May]226-may 's " niceness "[231-beaufort] was just what [a husband]2511-a husband should have wished to hear said of [[his]2511-a husband wife]553-his wife . The fact that [a coarseminded man]2513-a coarseminded man found [her]226-may lacking in attraction was simply another proof of [her]226-may quality ; yet the words sent a faint shiver through [his]645-her husband heart . What if " niceness "[226-may] carried to that supreme degree were only a negation , the curtain dropped before an emptiness ? As [he]645-her husband looked at [May]226-may , returning flushed and calm from [her]226-may final bull's - eye , [he]645-her husband had the feeling that [he]645-her husband had never yet lifted that curtain .

[She]226-may took the congratulations of [[her]226-may rivals]2505-her rivals and of [the rest of [the company]2516-the company]2515-the rest of the company with the simplicity that was [her]226-may crowning grace . [No one]601-no one could ever be jealous of [her]226-may triumphs because [she]226-may managed to give the feeling that [she]226-may would have been just as serene if [she]226-may had missed [them]2518-them . But when [her]226-may eyes met [[her]226-may husband]645-her husband 's [her]226-may face glowed with the pleasure [she]226-may saw in [his]645-her husband .

[[Mrs. Welland]219-mrs. welland 's basket - work [pony - carriage]2521-pony - carriage]2520-mrs. welland 's basket - work pony - carriage was waiting for [them]2522-them , and [they]2522-them drove off among [the dispersing carriages]2523-the dispersing carriages , [May]2524-may handling the reins and [Archer]215-archer sitting at [her]2524-may side .

The afternoon sunlight still lingered upon the bright lawns and shrubberies , and up and down [Bellevue Avenue]136-bellevue avenue rolled a double line of victorias , [dog - carts]2525-dog - carts , landaus and " vis - a - vis , "[2526-well - dressed ladies] carrying [well - dressed ladies]2526-well - dressed ladies and [gentlemen]4038-gentlemen away from [the Beaufort garden - party]2528-the beaufort garden - party , or homeward from [their]2522-them daily afternoon turn along [the Ocean Drive]2529-the ocean drive .

[Archer]215-archer acquiesced , and [she]2524-may turned the ponies down [Narragansett Avenue]137-narragansett avenue , crossed [Spring Street]138-spring street and drove out toward [the rocky moorland beyond]2531-the rocky moorland beyond . Since [she]237-old catherine had been the means of hastening [his]2547-his marriage [old Catherine]237-old catherine had shown to [Archer]215-archer the cordiality which a service rendered excites toward [the person]2548-the person served . [She]237-old catherine was persuaded that irrepressible passion was the cause of [his]2547-his impatience ; and being an ardent admirer of impulsiveness ( when it did not lead to the spending of money ) [she]237-old catherine always received [him]2547-his with a genial twinkle of complicity and a play of allusion to which [May]226-may seemed fortunately impervious .

[She]237-old catherine examined and appraised with much interest the diamond - tipped arrow which had been pinned on [May]226-may 's bosom at the conclusion of the match , remarking that in [her]237-old catherine day a filigree brooch would have been thought enough , but that there was no denying that [Beaufort]231-beaufort did things handsomely .

" Quite an heirloom , in fact , [[my]3973-the old lady dear]4004-my dear , "[3973-the old lady] [the old lady]3973-the old lady chuckled . " Run down and fetch [her]235-the countess olenska , like [a good grandson]4841-a good grandson ; [this pretty lady]4842-this pretty lady will describe the party to [me]226-may , "[226-may] [she]226-may said ; and [Archer]215-archer stood up as if in a dream .

[He]2556-he had heard [the Countess Olenska]235-the countess olenska 's name pronounced often enough during the year and a half since [they]2557-they had last met , and was even familiar with the main incidents of [her]235-the countess olenska life in the interval . " What am [I]215-archer ? [A son - in - law--]4843-a son - in - law-- "[215-archer] [Archer]215-archer thought .

[The figure at the end of the pier]2591-the figure at the end of the pier had not moved . [The boat]2606-the boat was gliding out on the receding tide . [He]511-the young man turned and walked up [the hill]2613-the hill .

" [I]2614-may 'm sorry [you]215-archer did n't find [Ellen]233-ellen -- [I]2614-may should have liked to see [her]233-ellen again , "[2614-may] [May]2614-may said as [they]2615-they drove [home]631-home through the dusk . " So indifferent to [[her]233-ellen friends]721-her friends , [I]2618-i mean ; giving up [New York]2-new york and [[her]233-ellen house]800-her house , and spending [her]233-ellen time with [such queer people]4846-such queer people . " It 's a pity [she]226-may ever married abroad then , "[226-may] said [May]226-may , in the placid tone with which [[her]226-may mother]587-her mother met [[Mr. Welland]335-mr. welland 's vagaries]2621-mr. welland 's vagaries ; and [Archer]215-archer felt [himself]2619-he gently relegated to the category of [unreasonable husbands]2622-unreasonable husbands .

[They]2623-they drove down [Bellevue Avenue]136-bellevue avenue and turned in between the chamfered wooden gate - posts surmounted by cast - iron lamps which marked the approach to [the Welland villa]2624-the welland villa . Lights were already shining through [its]2624-the welland villa windows , and [Archer]215-archer , as [the carriage]859-the carriage stopped , caught a glimpse of [[his]2619-he father - in - law]2626-his father - in - law , exactly as [he]2619-he had pictured [him]2626-his father - in - law , pacing [the drawing - room]964-the drawing - room , watch in hand and wearing the pained expression that [he]2619-he had long since found to be much more efficacious than anger .

[The young man]511-the young man , as [he]511-the young man followed [[his]511-the young man wife]553-his wife into [the hall]736-the hall , was conscious of a curious reversal of mood . There was something about the luxury of [the Welland house]2631-the welland house and the density of the Welland atmosphere , so charged with minute observances and exactions , that always stole into [his]511-the young man system like a narcotic . The heavy carpets , [the watchful servants]2632-the watchful servants , the perpetually reminding tick of disciplined clocks , the perpetually renewed stack of cards and invitations on [the hall]736-the hall table , the whole chain of tyrannical trifles binding one hour to the next , and [each member of [the household]2635-the household to [all the others]2636-all the others]2634-each member of the household to all the others , made any less systematised and affluent existence seem unreal and precarious . But now it was [the Welland house]2631-the welland house , and the life [he]511-the young man was expected to lead in [it]2631-the welland house , that had become unreal and irrelevant , and the brief scene on [the shore]2555-the shore , when [he]511-the young man had stood irresolute , halfway down [the bank]2586-the bank , was as close to [him]511-the young man as the blood in [his]511-the young man veins .

All night [he]511-the young man lay awake in [the big chintz bedroom at [May]226-may 's side]2640-the big chintz bedroom at may 's side , watching the moonlight slant along the carpet , and thinking of [Ellen Olenska]233-ellen driving [home]631-home across [the gleaming beaches]2642-the gleaming beaches behind [[Beaufort]231-beaufort 's trotters]2643-beaufort 's trotters .

XXII .

" A party for [the Blenkers]362-the blenkers -- [the Blenkers]362-the blenkers ? "[553-his wife]

[Mr. Welland]335-mr. welland laid down [his]335-mr. welland knife and fork and looked anxiously and incredulously across the luncheon - table at [[his]335-mr. welland wife]553-his wife , who , adjusting [her]553-his wife gold eye - glasses , read aloud , in the tone of high comedy :

" [Professor]4853-professor and [Mrs. Emerson Sillerton]444-mrs. emerson sillerton request the pleasure of [Mr.]4854-mr. and [[Mrs. Welland]219-mrs. welland 's company]4855-mrs. welland 's company at the meeting of [the Wednesday Afternoon Club]4856-the wednesday afternoon club on August 25th at 3 o'clock punctually . To meet [Mrs.]4857-mrs. and [the Misses Blenker]445-the misses blenker . "[553-his wife]

" [Red Gables]145-red gables , [Catherine Street]146-catherine street . R. S. V. P. "[553-his wife]

" Good gracious-- "[335-mr. welland] [Mr. Welland]335-mr. welland gasped , as if a second reading had been necessary to bring the monstrous absurdity of the thing home to [him]335-mr. welland .

" [Poor Amy Sillerton]446-amy sillerton -- [you]335-mr. welland never can tell what [[her]446-amy sillerton husband]645-her husband will do next , "[219-mrs. welland] [Mrs. Welland]219-mrs. welland sighed . " [I]219-mrs. welland suppose [he]645-her husband 's just discovered [the Blenkers]362-the blenkers . "[219-mrs. welland]

[Professor Emerson Sillerton]447-professor emerson sillerton was a thorn in the side of [Newport]105-newport society ; and a thorn that could not be plucked out , for it grew on [a venerable and venerated family tree]2645-a venerable and venerated family tree . [He]447-professor emerson sillerton was , as [people]619-people said , [a man who had had " every advantage]4859-a man who had had " every advantage . "[447-professor emerson sillerton] [[His]447-professor emerson sillerton father]2392-his father was [[Sillerton Jackson]225-mr. jackson 's uncle]2648-sillerton jackson 's uncle , [[his]447-professor emerson sillerton mother]512-his mother [a Pennilow of [Boston]147-boston]2650-a pennilow of boston ; on each side there was wealth and position , and mutual suitability . [Nothing]2651-nothing -- as [Mrs. Welland]219-mrs. welland had often remarked -- nothing on [earth]882-earth obliged [Emerson Sillerton]447-professor emerson sillerton to be [an archaeologist]2653-an archaeologist , or indeed [a Professor of any sort]2654-a professor of any sort , or to live in [Newport]105-newport in winter , or do any of the other revolutionary things that [he]447-professor emerson sillerton did . But at least , if [he]447-professor emerson sillerton was going to break with tradition and flout society in the face , [he]447-professor emerson sillerton need not have married [poor [Amy Dagonet]448-amy dagonet , who had a right to expect " something different , "[448-amy dagonet] and money enough to keep [[her]448-amy dagonet own carriage]2656-her own carriage]2655-poor amy dagonet , who had a right to expect " something different , " and money enough to keep her own carriage .

[No one in the Mingott set]2657-no one in the mingott set could understand why [Amy Sillerton]446-amy sillerton had submitted so tamely to the eccentricities of [a husband who filled [the house]516-the house with [long - haired men]2660-long - haired men and [short - haired women]2661-short - haired women]2658-a husband who filled the house with long - haired men and short - haired women , and , when [he]447-professor emerson sillerton travelled , took [her]446-amy sillerton to explore tombs in [Yucatan]148-yucatan instead of going to [Paris]7-paris or [Italy]65-italy . But there [they]2662-they were , set in [their]2662-they ways , and apparently unaware that [they]2662-they were different from [other people]4692-other people ; and when [they]2662-they gave one of [their]2662-they dreary annual garden - parties [every family on]2664-every family on [the Cliffs]149-the cliffs , because of the [Sillerton - Pennilow - Dagonet]150-sillerton - pennilow - dagonet connection , had to draw lots and send [an unwilling representative]2665-an unwilling representative .

" It 's a wonder , "[219-mrs. welland] [Mrs. Welland]219-mrs. welland remarked , " that [they]2662-they did n't choose the Cup Race day ! Do [you]4860-you remember , two years ago , [their]2662-they giving a party for [a black man]4861-a black man on the day of [Julia Mingott]449-julia mingott 's the dansant ? Luckily this time there 's nothing else going on that [I]219-mrs. welland know of -- for of course [some of [us]2662-they]4862-some of us will have to go . "[219-mrs. welland]

[Mr. Welland]335-mr. welland sighed nervously . " ' Some of [us]2662-they , ' [[my]335-mr. welland dear]4004-my dear -- more than one ? Three o'clock is such a very awkward hour . [I]335-mr. welland have to be here at half - past three to take [my]335-mr. welland drops : it 's really no use trying to follow [Bencomb]450-dr. bencomb 's new treatment if [I]335-mr. welland do n't do it systematically ; and if [I]335-mr. welland join [you]4004-my dear later , of course [I]335-mr. welland shall miss [my]335-mr. welland drive . "[335-mr. welland] At the thought [he]335-mr. welland laid down [his]335-mr. welland knife and fork again , and a flush of anxiety rose to [his]335-mr. welland finely - wrinkled cheek .

" There 's no reason why [you]4004-my dear should go at all , [[my]553-his wife dear]4004-my dear , "[553-his wife] [[his]335-mr. welland wife]553-his wife answered with a cheerfulness that had become automatic . " [I]553-his wife have some cards to leave at [the other end of [Bellevue Avenue]136-bellevue avenue]4865-the other end of bellevue avenue , and [I]553-his wife 'll drop in at about half - past three and stay long enough to make poor [Amy]446-amy sillerton feel that [she]446-amy sillerton has n't been slighted . "[553-his wife] [She]553-his wife glanced hesitatingly at [[her]553-his wife daughter]534-her daughter . " And if [Newland]215-archer 's afternoon is provided for perhaps [May]226-may can drive [you]534-her daughter out with the ponies , and try [their]4866-their new russet harness . "[553-his wife]

It was a principle in [the Welland family]2668-the welland family that [people]619-people 's days and hours should be what [Mrs. Welland]219-mrs. welland called " provided for . "[219-mrs. welland] The melancholy possibility of having to " kill time "[219-mrs. welland] ( especially for [those who did not care for whist or solitaire )]2670-those who did not care for whist or solitaire ) was a vision that haunted [her]219-mrs. welland as the spectre of [the unemployed]2671-the unemployed haunts [the philanthropist]2672-the philanthropist . Another of [her]219-mrs. welland principles was that [parents]4714-parents should never ( at least visibly ) interfere with the plans of [[their]4714-parents married children]2674-their married children ; and the difficulty of adjusting this respect for [May]226-may 's independence with the exigency of [Mr. Welland]335-mr. welland 's claims could be overcome only by the exercise of an ingenuity which left not a second of [Mrs. Welland]219-mrs. welland 's own time unprovided for .

" Of course [I]2675-may 'll drive with [Papa]402-papa -- I'm sure [Newland]215-archer will find something to do , "[2675-may] [May]2675-may said , in a tone that gently reminded [[her]2675-may husband]645-her husband of [his]645-her husband lack of response . It was a cause of constant distress to [Mrs. Welland]219-mrs. welland that [[her]219-mrs. welland son - in - law]2677-her son - in - law showed so little foresight in planning [his]2677-her son - in - law days . Often already , during the fortnight that [he]2677-her son - in - law had passed under [her]219-mrs. welland roof , when [she]219-mrs. welland enquired how [he]2677-her son - in - law meant to spend [his]2677-her son - in - law afternoon , [he]2677-her son - in - law had answered paradoxically : " Oh , [I]2677-her son - in - law think for a change [I]2677-her son - in - law 'll just save it instead of spending it-- "[2677-her son - in - law] and once , when [she]219-mrs. welland and [May]226-may had had to go on a long - postponed round of afternoon calls , [he]2677-her son - in - law had confessed to having lain all the afternoon under a rock on [the beach below [the house]516-the house]2678-the beach below the house .

" [Newland]215-archer never seems to look ahead , "[219-mrs. welland] [Mrs. Welland]219-mrs. welland once ventured to complain to [[her]219-mrs. welland daughter]534-her daughter ; and [May]2681-may answered serenely : " No ; but [you]534-her daughter see it does n't matter , because when there 's nothing particular to do [he]2677-her son - in - law reads a book . "[2681-may]

" Ah , yes -- like [[his]2677-her son - in - law father]2392-his father ! "[219-mrs. welland] [Mrs. Welland]219-mrs. welland agreed , as if allowing for an inherited oddity ; and after that the question of [Newland]215-archer 's unemployment was tacitly dropped .

Nevertheless , as the day for the Sillerton reception approached , [May]226-may began to show a natural solicitude for [his]2677-her son - in - law welfare , and to suggest a tennis match at [the Chiverses ']2682-the chiverses ' , or a sail on [[Julius Beaufort]231-beaufort 's cutter]2683-julius beaufort 's cutter , as a means of atoning for [her]226-may temporary desertion . " [I]226-may shall be back by six , [you]226-may know , [dear]3991-dear : [Papa]402-papa never drives later than that-- "[226-may] and [she]226-may was not reassured till [Archer]215-archer said that [he]2677-her son - in - law thought of hiring a run - about and driving up [the island]2610-the island to [a stud - farm]2685-a stud - farm to look at a second horse for [her]226-may brougham . [They]2686-they had been looking for this horse for some time , and the suggestion was so acceptable that [May]226-may glanced at [[her]226-may mother]587-her mother as if to say : " [You]587-her mother see [he]402-papa knows how to plan out [his]402-papa time as well as any of [us]2686-they . "[226-may]

The idea of [the stud - farm]2688-the stud - farm and the brougham horse had germinated in [Archer]215-archer 's mind on the very day when the Emerson Sillerton invitation had first been mentioned ; but [he]2677-her son - in - law had kept it to [himself]2677-her son - in - law as if there were something clandestine in the plan , and discovery might prevent its execution . [He]2677-her son - in - law had , however , taken the precaution to engage in advance a runabout with a pair of old livery - stable trotters that could still do [their]2689-their eighteen miles on [level roads]2690-level roads ; and at two o'clock , hastily deserting the luncheon - table , [he]2677-her son - in - law sprang into [the light carriage]2691-the light carriage and drove off .

The day was perfect . A breeze from the north drove little puffs of white cloud across an ultramarine sky , with a bright sea running under it . [Bellevue Avenue]136-bellevue avenue was empty at that hour , and after dropping the stable - lad at [the corner of [Mill Street Archer]151-mill street archer]2692-the corner of mill street archer turned down [the Old Beach Road]152-the old beach road and drove across [Eastman 's Beach]153-eastman 's beach .

[He]2677-her son - in - law had the feeling of unexplained excitement with which , on half - holidays at [school]2693-school , [he]2677-her son - in - law used to start off into the unknown . Taking [his]2677-her son - in - law pair at an easy gait , [he]2677-her son - in - law counted on reaching [the stud - farm]2688-the stud - farm , which was not far beyond [Paradise Rocks]154-paradise rocks , before three o'clock ; so that , after looking over the horse ( and trying [him]2677-her son - in - law if [he]2677-her son - in - law seemed promising ) [he]2677-her son - in - law would still have four golden hours to dispose of .

As soon as [he]2677-her son - in - law heard of [[the Sillerton]446-amy sillerton 's party]2695-the sillerton 's party [he]2677-her son - in - law had said to [himself]2677-her son - in - law that [the Marchioness Manson]2696-the marchioness manson would certainly come to [Newport]105-newport with [the Blenkers]362-the blenkers , and that [Madame Olenska]241-madame olenska might again take the opportunity of spending the day with [[her]241-madame olenska grandmother]834-her grandmother . At any rate , [the Blenker habitation]2698-the blenker habitation would probably be deserted , and [he]2677-her son - in - law would be able , without indiscretion , to satisfy a vague curiosity concerning it . [He]2677-her son - in - law was not sure that [he]2677-her son - in - law wanted to see [the Countess Olenska]235-the countess olenska again ; but ever since [he]2677-her son - in - law had looked at [her]235-the countess olenska from [the path above [the bay]2535-the bay]2699-the path above the bay [he]2677-her son - in - law had wanted , irrationally and indescribably , to see [the place [she]235-the countess olenska was living in]2701-the place she was living in , and to follow the movements of [her]235-the countess olenska imagined figure as [he]2677-her son - in - law had watched the real one in [the summer - house]2600-the summer - house . The longing was with [him]2677-her son - in - law day and night , an incessant undefinable craving , like the sudden whim of [a sick man]2703-a sick man for food or drink once tasted and long since forgotten . [He]2677-her son - in - law could not see beyond the craving , or picture what it might lead to , for [he]2677-her son - in - law was not conscious of any wish to speak to [Madame Olenska]241-madame olenska or to hear [her]235-the countess olenska voice . [He]2677-her son - in - law simply felt that if [he]2677-her son - in - law could carry away the vision of the spot of [earth]882-earth [she]235-the countess olenska walked on , and the way the sky and [sea]2705-sea enclosed [it]2706-it , [the rest of [the world]561-the world]2707-the rest of the world might seem less empty .

When [he]2677-her son - in - law reached [the stud - farm]2688-the stud - farm a glance showed [him]2677-her son - in - law that the horse was not what [he]2677-her son - in - law wanted ; nevertheless [he]2677-her son - in - law took a turn behind [it]2688-the stud - farm in order to prove to [himself]2677-her son - in - law that [he]2677-her son - in - law was not in a hurry . But at three o'clock [he]2677-her son - in - law shook out the reins over the trotters and turned into [the by - roads leading to [Portsmouth]132-portsmouth]2710-the by - roads leading to portsmouth . The wind had dropped and a faint haze on the horizon showed that a fog was waiting to steal up [the Saconnet]155-the saconnet on the turn of the tide ; but all about [him]2677-her son - in - law fields and woods were steeped in golden light .

[He]2677-her son - in - law drove past [grey - shingled farm - houses in [orchards]2712-orchards]2711-grey - shingled farm - houses in orchards , past [hay - fields]2713-hay - fields and [groves of oak]2714-groves of oak , past villages with white steeples rising sharply into the fading sky ; and at last , after stopping to ask the way of [some men at work in [a field]2716-a field]2715-some men at work in a field , [he]2677-her son - in - law turned down [a lane]2717-a lane between [high banks of goldenrod and brambles]2718-high banks of goldenrod and brambles . At the end of [the lane]2719-the lane was the blue glimmer of [the river]1924-the river ; to the left , standing in front of a clump of oaks and maples , [he]2677-her son - in - law saw [a long tumble - down house]2721-a long tumble - down house with white paint peeling from [its]2721-a long tumble - down house clapboards .

On [the road]1836-the road - side facing the gateway stood one of [the open sheds in which [the New Englander]451-the new englander shelters [his]2677-her son - in - law farming implements]2723-the open sheds in which the new englander shelters his farming implements and [visitors]1782-visitors " hitch "[1782-visitors] [their]1782-visitors " teams . "[215-archer] [Archer]215-archer , jumping down , led [[his]2677-her son - in - law pair]2725-his pair into [the shed]2726-the shed , and after tying [them]2725-his pair to a post turned toward [the house]516-the house . The patch of lawn before [it]2728-it had relapsed into [a hay - field]2729-a hay - field ; but to the left [an overgrown box - garden full of dahlias and rusty rose - bushes]2730-an overgrown box - garden full of dahlias and rusty rose - bushes encircled [a ghostly summer - house of trellis - work]2731-a ghostly summer - house of trellis - work that had once been white , surmounted by a wooden Cupid who had lost [his]2677-her son - in - law bow and arrow but continued to take ineffectual aim .

[Archer]215-archer leaned for a while against the gate . [No one]601-no one was in sight , and not a sound came from the open windows of [the house]516-the house : [a grizzled Newfoundland dozing before the door]2734-a grizzled newfoundland dozing before the door seemed as ineffectual [a guardian as the arrowless Cupid]2735-a guardian as the arrowless cupid . It was strange to think that [this place of silence and decay]2736-this place of silence and decay was [the home of [the turbulent Blenkers]2738-the turbulent blenkers]2737-the home of the turbulent blenkers ; yet [Archer]215-archer was sure that [he]2677-her son - in - law was not mistaken .

For a long time [he]2677-her son - in - law stood there , content to take in the scene , and gradually falling under its drowsy spell ; but at length [he]2677-her son - in - law roused [himself]2677-her son - in - law to the sense of the passing time . Should [he]2677-her son - in - law look [his]2677-her son - in - law fill and then drive away ? [He]2677-her son - in - law stood irresolute , wishing suddenly to see the inside of [the house]516-the house , so that [he]2677-her son - in - law might picture [the room that [Madame Olenska]241-madame olenska sat in]2740-the room that madame olenska sat in . There was nothing to prevent [his]2677-her son - in - law walking up to the door and ringing the bell ; if , as [he]2677-her son - in - law supposed , [she]241-madame olenska was away with the rest of [the party]2741-the party , [he]2677-her son - in - law could easily give [his]2677-her son - in - law name , and ask permission to go into [the sitting - room]2742-the sitting - room to write a message .

But instead , [he]2677-her son - in - law crossed [the lawn]2430-the lawn and turned toward [the box - garden]2744-the box - garden . As [he]2677-her son - in - law entered [it]2744-the box - garden [he]2677-her son - in - law caught sight of something bright - coloured in [the summer - house]2600-the summer - house , and presently made it out to be a pink parasol . The parasol drew [him]2677-her son - in - law like a magnet : [he]2677-her son - in - law was sure it was [hers]241-madame olenska . [He]2677-her son - in - law went into [the summer - house]2600-the summer - house , and sitting down on the rickety seat picked up the silken thing and looked at its carved handle , which was made of some rare wood that gave out an aromatic scent . [Archer]215-archer lifted the handle to [his]2677-her son - in - law lips .

[He]2677-her son - in - law heard a rustle of skirts against the box , and sat motionless , leaning on the parasol handle with clasped hands , and letting the rustle come nearer without lifting [his]2677-her son - in - law eyes . [He]2677-her son - in - law had always known that this must happen ...

" Oh , [Mr. Archer]256-archer ! "[2677-her son - in - law] exclaimed a loud young voice ; and looking up [he]2677-her son - in - law saw before [him]2677-her son - in - law [the youngest and largest of [the Blenker girls]2748-the blenker girls]2747-the youngest and largest of the blenker girls , blonde and blowsy , in bedraggled muslin . A red blotch on one of [her]241-madame olenska cheeks seemed to show that it had recently been pressed against a pillow , and [her]241-madame olenska half - awakened eyes stared at [him]2677-her son - in - law hospitably but confusedly .

" Gracious -- where did [you]256-archer drop from ? [I]241-madame olenska must have been sound asleep in the hammock . [Everybody else]4381-everybody else has gone to [Newport]105-newport . Did [you]256-archer ring ? "[241-madame olenska] [she]241-madame olenska incoherently enquired .

[Archer]256-archer 's confusion was greater than [hers]241-madame olenska . " [I]256-archer -- no -- that is , [I]256-archer was just going to . [I]256-archer had to come up [the island]2610-the island to see about a horse , and [I]256-archer drove over on a chance of finding [Mrs. Blenker]412-mrs. blenker and [[your]412-mrs. blenker visitors]4871-your visitors . But [the house]516-the house seemed empty -- so [I]256-archer sat down to wait . "[256-archer]

[Miss Blenker]452-miss blenker , shaking off the fumes of sleep , looked at [him]2677-her son - in - law with increasing interest . " [The house]516-the house IS empty . [Mother]348-mother 's not [here]4019-here , or [the Marchioness]2030-the marchioness -- or anybody but [me]241-madame olenska . "[241-madame olenska] [Her]241-madame olenska glance became faintly reproachful . " Did n't [you]2677-her son - in - law know that [Professor]447-professor emerson sillerton and [Mrs. Sillerton]444-mrs. emerson sillerton are giving a garden - party for [mother]903-mother and all of [us]4877-us this afternoon ? It was too unlucky that [I]241-madame olenska could n't go ; but [I]241-madame olenska 've had a sore throat , and [mother]903-mother was afraid of the drive [home]631-home this evening .
